My hours in this game on Steam aren't indicative of the actual hours that I've put into this trilogy as a whole having played the original released on the 360, and also having played the LE through EA Origin when I had a subscription to that when the LE originally released. That being said.....

One big negative against the LE is that you have to have the EA app installed and opened during gameplay in order to play it. 

That aside however the Legendary Edition is great collection of one of the best gaming trilogies to ever release. While some work was done to bring ME1 up to date it is still rough around the edges and unless you have a fondness for it from having played it back in the day the gameplay could drag your experience down, but the story is well worth it regardless. However ME2's gameplay is a big improvement and still holds up really well as does ME3's. 

I would recommend however to wait for the game to go on sale because why would you spend $60 on a 3.5 year old remaster of games that are between 17-12 years old. Not saying the experience these game provides isn't worth it, but if you look at the price history every few months it goes on sale for less than $10 so just save yourself some money.

I can't explain how genuinely I wish that I could have played Mass Effect as a teen. This story is breathtaking and heartbreaking and there are so many phenomenal moments that left me openly crying in front of my screen. I leave the final game with my heart both full and mourning. Only wanting to spend a hundred more hours with the crew from the Normandy at the very least.

It's so funny ... all my friends begged me to play it, saying it was something I'd love. I wished I listened to them sooner. I'd heard how the ending went, I used to watch all the Shepard/Vakarian scenes on YouTube as the games came out. And despite knowing so much, there were a lot of secrets still to be had within the game, and the final moments of ME3 still hit so hard that I could only sit there and sniffle and watch through my tears at the impact of Shepard's final sacrifice had on the galaxy. 

I don't play games for combat really, so I'm not really up in arms at how annoying the first game is to play. I feel like the Legendary Edition fixed a lot of the issues I had when I tried my hand at playing the first game all those years ago. And I'm so glad because it made it so enjoyable that I finally got past the place I had always gotten stuck. 

Quite literally one of my favorite stories I've ever had the joy of interacting with ... I can't give it enough praise. All I can say is that I will come back to this game over and over again in my own lifetime to relive the legend of Shepard. <3

What a game! The story is the real driver here. There's a few things that really show the age: the combat, the binary good/bad choices (called Renegade/Paragon in the game), and the lack of 3D movement, but you get used to it and you really don't need it. The true excellence of the game comes from the relationships you build with people and how each person has their own mindset. Each faction has its own motivation and goals. Some factions are your enemy one minute, and depending on your choices and your own motivations, your ally the next. The individual character development and your impact on them really creates an immersive experience. If you like titles like Fable and the Witcher, you'll love this game. If you're a completionist, you'll likely get 180+ hours out of this game on one playthrough.

Overall:  This is a really great series.  The story is epic.  Just an instant sci-fi classic.  If your intentions are to play on a standard PC then absolutely buy it and enjoy.  The series is worth multiple runs.  Bioware hit it absolutely out of the park.  
PC:  My complaints really come from EA and experiences with the steam deck. The only downer is the Internet/EA App requirement.  

Steam Deck Experience:  This game will run on the deck.  In fact it runs great.  But if you plan on playing on the go.  Don't purchase.  The EA app makes it impossible to play without the internet connection.  Even if you start the game with an internet connection but you lose the connection you will need to play something else.  The old Origin App you could at least play the game offline with workarounds.  They patched out the Origin app and upgraded to the EA app but refuse to make it a steam native game like they are with the upcoming Dragon Age.  When you go to the EA forums to make a suggestion the community managers are often dismissive and hostile.  They simply are indifferent.  Nothing will make you feel more like a clown for buying one of their products then interacting with their teams on the their forums.

[b]Why the Positive Review?[/b]
->  The Mass Effect Legendary Edition is a triumphant return to one of gaming's most beloved trilogies.  Reliving Commander Shepard's journey was an absolute joy, and the updated visuals, gameplay tweaks, and inclusion of nearly all DLC make this the definitive way to experience the Mass Effect saga.

[b]The Good:[/b]
->  A remastered experience that breathes new life into the trilogy with enhanced visuals and improved gameplay.
->  A sprawling and unforgettable sci-fi narrative with impactful choices and memorable characters.
->  Deeply engaging character interactions and relationships that foster genuine emotional connections.
->  The inclusion of almost all DLC content, adding hours of additional gameplay and enriching the overall experience (Citadel DLC, you know what I'm talking about!).

[b]The Bad:[/b]
->  The absence of Pinnacle Station, while understandable, is still a slight disappointment for some fans.
->  Some minor bugs and glitches remain despite the remastering efforts.
->  The first game's combat still feels somewhat dated compared to the sequels;
-> Also, let's completely ignore the Mass Effect multiplayer, which isn't good.

132.6 hours. My most recent, very completionist playthrough of the ME Trilogy on Insanity difficulty. I originally pirated the trilogy back in 2013, and played the "extended edition" of ME3. It came at a time I was in a deep depression, and it did a lot to get me through it and pull me out of it. I still keep finding new interactions, new paths, things I didn't know about, and new ways to explore the content of the games. 

And I know I will play this trilogy again. But for now, it's October and Signalis is up next.

I bought this product thinking it was one game, and was incensed to spend almost a full day downloading and installing it, but it made sense once I found out I had the entire trilogy.  I cared not at all for 3 and only a little for 2, which I tried out for a moment and lost interest in almost immediately, but the original Mass Effect hooked me immediately, I was absolutely blown away by how beautiful and immersive the interactive story was.  Gameplay was a little weak, overcomplected and fairly uninteresting, mostly a distraction from plot events and character interaction, but I got extremely attached to "my Shepherd", as players of Mass Effect usually do.

And then I forgot my password to log into the EA app, and couldn't figure out which email address I'd tied to it, so there was no recovering my passsword.  I should have realized how bad of a sign that was, but I could still play the game, so I continued on my merry way without a care.

And then one day the game simply wouldn't launch.

Bioware created one of the greatest games of all time, a legendary achievement in interactive storytelling, set in a fictional world very nearly the equal of Star Trek or the Lord of the Rings...and then EA destroyed it by shoving all the players into a box.  Why, I won't pretend to know; maybe they wanted to harvest information which they could sell to other companies, or maybe they just have a hidebound insistence on industry-wide "best practices" which are secretly instituted by a small conspiracy of would-be overlords, who think they can control the world by hacking into video gamers' bank accounts through spyware disguised as an End-User License Agreement.  The mind boggles trying to make sense of such a colossal degree of malicious corporate ineptitude.  

Either way, my short-lived love affair with Mass Effect one only serves to make it more of a tragedy that the save files I put 20 hours into perfecting are now inaccessible to me, perhaps forever.  I paid $30 for the original 2007 Mass Effect game, hoping I might be able to pay some genius modder even more money to retrofit my existing save files for the older program, or else I'll just have to create new characters and slowly fall back in love with the game, while trying not to remember the pain of the original experience.  Meanwhile, my advice to everyone is simple: DON'T buy this game, or any other game that EA has put its greasy, intrusive fingers upon.  Nobody should ever have to sign into a globalist app just to play a single-player game.  Nobody should lose all their save files to a computer glitch or a forgotten password.  Don't let the crimes of EA go unpunished.  Vote with your wallets and buy from literally anyone else.

do yourself a favor and don't play it. Don't fall into the trap. I wanted to finish it so bad because of how cool it felt to have decisions carry over a whole trilogy, but it's so badly designed it'll be tortourous to see how such potential just falls flat because of how horribly done and directed everything is.
for starters, and this alone is a war crime, the controls will never stop being awful, they'll just be in different ways. on the third game, the game literally can't handle inputs sometimes and just gets locked ADS or the shooting gets locked and when you let go of the mouse buttons, it'll keep on going and you'll have to spam click to make it stop (this will happen at least every 20/30 minutes).
the game mechanics will be awfully unclear through all trilogy so good luck just winging it or not caring.


THE MOST IMPORTANT PART:


The story is the most unsatisfying mess imaginable.
first, it suffers from the lie of choice where it's just "make this dumb choice that is objectively incorrect and should go wrong 100% because it'll actually yield better results for script reasons. Want to make the smart choice? sure, but now half the planet died, a puppy was tortured and half your party will remind you how much of a villain you are for the rest of the trilogy." there's only choice if you somehow want to be guilt tripped all throughout the game.

secondly, AND THE BIGGEST SIN OF THEM ALL, good choices are locked behind extremely convoluted, impossible to predict and completely illogical requirements (the final mission of ME2 is an absolute trainwreck of this). There's a million examples of this, but the last nail that made me uninstall the game without finishing it is that on ME3, I have to choose between annhiliting a whole inoccent race, or annhiliting a not so inoccent but still good race PLUS my favorite party member that I've loved since ME1. I can't end that war peacefully even though I have max paragon points only because on ME2, I chose ONE different dialogue that has nothing to do with this, it wasn't important at all on the grand scheme of things, wasn't even a paragon dialogue and had no consequences at all up until now.

Don't play this trainwreck, please, you'll just be left with an unfinished game, 100+ hours wasted, and an awful mess of unresolved feelings.

TLDR: the game is designed horribly, controls are awful, the third game is extremely buggy and borderline unplayable sometimes, and the story is absurdly unsatisfying and annoying. but please I urge you to at least read my last paragraph about the biggest sin of this game before buying it.

The Mass Effect Legendary Edition is a complete remaster of BioWare's iconic sci-fi trilogy—Mass Effect, Mass Effect 2, and Mass Effect 3. With upgraded graphics, refined mechanics, and quality-of-life improvements, this collection brings Commander Shepard's journey back to life for a new generation. Here’s a detailed look at each aspect of the Legendary Edition.

Graphics & Visuals
The remaster offers a striking visual overhaul, especially for the first game, bringing it closer to the standards set by Mass Effect 3. The textures, lighting, and models are significantly improved, making each world feel more immersive. The atmospheric enhancements to planets and locations like Eden Prime, Feros, and the Citadel allow players to experience the scale and alien beauty of the Mass Effect universe in a new light. Character models have received high-definition makeovers, which, coupled with improved lighting, make the scenes more cinematic.

Highlights:

Enhanced 4K resolution and HDR support.
Updated textures, shaders, and post-processing effects.
Revamped lighting makes environments like Ilos and the Shadow Broker’s lair feel alive and detailed.
Gameplay & Mechanics
The gameplay experience is much smoother and more refined. The first Mass Effect, which had combat mechanics that felt outdated, has been reworked significantly. Combat in the original game now feels closer to the seamless action of its sequels, with improved aiming and better cover mechanics. Additionally, squad commands and abilities have become more accessible and fluid across all three titles.

The Mako vehicle, infamous for its clunky handling in the first game, has been overhauled with a less bouncy, more controlled feel, making exploration much more enjoyable. The RPG mechanics, particularly in the first game, retain their depth, with modern tweaks that improve the pacing.

Highlights:

Enhanced combat mechanics in Mass Effect 1, with better aiming and weapon feedback.
Mako vehicle handling improvements make planetary exploration smoother.
Unified keybinds and controls across all three games streamline the experience.
Story & Characters
Mass Effect is celebrated for its story-driven gameplay, and this trilogy is a masterclass in character development, choice, and consequence. Players guide Commander Shepard, a customizable protagonist, through a galactic conflict involving ancient machines called the Reapers. The choices you make in each game carry over, impacting relationships, alliances, and outcomes in increasingly dramatic ways.

The Legendary Edition doesn’t alter the story but adds polish to dialogue and animation. Characters like Garrus, Liara, Tali, and Mordin are even more engaging with updated expressions and textures, which make their iconic lines and emotional moments feel fresh and impactful. However, the Mass Effect 3 ending has only received minor tweaks, with the Extended Cut now the default, which does provide more clarity but may still leave some players divided.

Highlights:

Iconic characters and nuanced relationships deepen with remastered visuals.
Choices carry across all three games, creating a unique narrative experience.
The Extended Cut ending for Mass Effect 3 adds better context for the trilogy’s conclusion.
Quality-of-Life Improvements
BioWare focused on streamlining gameplay, with faster load times and a unified character creator, making it easier to maintain a consistent Shepard throughout the trilogy. The Legendary Edition also includes an autosave function, reducing the frustration of losing progress during missions. Additionally, the Legendary Edition combines all DLC packs—except Pinnacle Station due to lost source code—giving players access to the full experience, from story-rich expansions to unique weapons and armor sets.

Highlights:

Unified character creator across the trilogy for continuity.
All major DLC included for a complete narrative experience.
Improved load times and an autosave feature.
Sound & Music
The audio design and music remain as impactful as ever. Jack Wall’s compositions add depth to the narrative, enhancing the emotional tone of each game. The remaster adds subtle clarity to audio, though the changes here are minor compared to visuals. The soundtrack, from the melancholy of Vigil’s theme to the adrenaline-pumping Suicide Mission in Mass Effect 2, is beautifully integrated and unchanged, which fans will appreciate.

Highlights:

Iconic soundtrack with improved clarity.
High-quality voice acting remains one of the series’ strengths.
Minor adjustments to audio fidelity, primarily in environmental effects.
Performance
On modern consoles, Mass Effect Legendary Edition performs smoothly, with options for favoring performance (60 fps) or graphics quality (4K) on consoles like the PS5 and Xbox Series X. On PC, the game runs even more fluidly, with customizable settings and support for ultrawide monitors, bringing a cinematic feel to the trilogy’s expansive environments.

Final Verdict
The Mass Effect Legendary Edition is a respectful, polished remaster that succeeds in preserving the soul of the original games while making meaningful improvements. For newcomers, it's the perfect gateway into an iconic sci-fi saga. For veterans, it’s a welcome return that respects their nostalgia while adding fresh layers of beauty and refinement.

Pros:

Stunning visual upgrades that make the galaxy feel alive.
Improved combat and mechanics, especially in Mass Effect 1.
Unified character and DLC integration for a streamlined experience.
Cons:

Some minor bugs and glitches remain.
Ending controversy remains unresolved for some players.
Limited gameplay changes in Mass Effect 3.
Score: 9/10

I've always loved Mass Effect.  I remember originally buying ME1 and ME2 second hand from Game for the Xbox 360 and I absolutely loved them the instant I played them.  I remember replaying both games several times in order to get the ideal outcomes for the (then) upcoming ME3.  ME3 then came out not long after and it was the first game I ordered as the collector's edition, and first one I bought all DLC for (it was a very different time back in 2012).  I've lost count of the number of full trilogy playthroughs I've completed.  

When I moved on from the 360, moving over to the PS4, I sold my former console, and with it, the original ME trilogy copies I had.  I remember being disappointed that I couldn't play them as they were always my go to games to replay over and over again.  

I was therefore thrilled when they announced the Legendary Edition.  I actually own two separate copies of it; one for the PS4 and one on Steam.  The PS4 copy was first when it first came out and I blitzed through it like it was 2012 again.  The Steam copy was more recent (just a few days ago at time of writing) as I now mainly use my gaming PC.  

If you love RPGs (especially the classics like SWKOTOR) you will love this game and I would highly recommend it.

It's Mass Effect, what more could you want?*

This is *the* 'choices matter' Action RPG (From a narrative perspective, if not from a build-choices one) that set the groundwork for the modern RPG scene as we know it (For better and for worse; I don't think that detracts from Mass Effect, though). 

Of the individual games, I will say that the first one remains just a bit rough around the edges, but the actual experience can be exhilarating in a narrative sense (And the simplicity of the actual gameplay is at least *fun* when it comes to how overpowered a good Biotic build can be). The second game is the sweet spot for most people, in terms of having both a satisfying narrative (Which is weaker than the first one's overall, and has better pay-off but worse build-up than the final game) and satisfying gameplay.

ME3 remains ME3, which is a shame in some respects (Nothing can *fully* salvage the ending, but at least with the Citadel DLC bundled-in you shouldn't feel too oppressed by the lack of closure it brings), but it remains the best Third-Person Shooter I've ever played, and strikes a genuinely strong balance between the first two games' RPG elements to allow for some immensely fun replay value, both mechanically *and* narratively.

If you've always wanted to *try* an RPG, a Third-Person Shooter, or specifically a hybrid of the two, and you've never really known where to start...you couldn't do much better than this.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

*(Besides ME3's multiplayer, anyway)

The Mass Effect series is one of the best sci-fi games ever... until the ending of ME3. Mass Effect 3 was Game of Thrones Season 8, before Game of Thrones Season 8. There were hints that the story was going off the rails and the writers had their heads too far up their collective posteriors earlier in ME3, but wow did they think far too much of themselves when it came time to tie everything up, and in so doing completely broke the whole series and the universe they built. It's one of those endings that make less and less sense the more you think about it. 

But aside from that absolute godawful burning tire dump of the final moments of the trilogy, ME1 and ME2 and parts of ME3 were something truly special. Garrus, Tali, Liara, Wrex, Mordin, etc. The characters, personalities, and their stories were something I still remembered, even after I put ME3 down immediately after finishing it and didn't touch it again until now, 12 years later. 

This game trilogy could have been so much more. But it has stuck with me in a way almost none other has. So for that at least, I must give it a recommendation.

Most players play Mass Effect the wrong way when they play it first. It’s one of my favorite video games of all time and made me continue to play video games after I passed out of college. I remember feeling awestruck as the credits rolled the first time I played the first part of the trilogy. Here’s a guide if you are playing for the first time:

- Pre-game history mostly matters in terms of dialogue and missions in the first Mass Effect.
- Playing as Soldier class means that the game becomes just another shooter. Explore Mass Effect's unique combat options.
- Mass Effect has a character creator, but a serious Mass Effect fan like me who is a hardcore gamer prefers female Shepard, or FemShep as custom female. Experienced gamers might look down on you if you judge somebody for playing as a female. It opens you up to a different worldview.
- Mass Effect is mostly a story driven open world role playing game in which you can take any option you want so long as the dialogue wheel allows it.
- Choices matter and carry over into the sequels. Explore dialogue options.
- The game hits you hard with the idea of martyrdom. Don't look up online guides and spoil a role playing game for yourself. In real life, sometimes you cannot figure out why something happened.
- You are a soldier. Play the role playing game in that mindset. Mass Effect is well written.
- The game is written in the vein that humans are new to galactic politics. React to dialogues keeping that in mind. You are not in New York, Tokyo or New Delhi in the game.

Other than that, prepare to play as one of the greatest video game heroes of all time.

I, have never been disappointed with any of Bioware games that I’ve played thus far. I’ve always loved their writing, the gameplay and their diverse characters.

[b]Mass Effect 1[/b]:
It was a good opening to the series. I loved the writing, the characters and the voice acting for the most part.

The gameplay was “okay”. The shooting was fun for the most part; Exploring planets was tedious and repetitive, especially with how empty they were. “Try to drive over this large hill to maybe find a resource to scan. Go to this location to blowup/shoot some enemies.”

[b]Mass Effect 2[/b]:
The second game felt much more refined. The gameplay was far better than the first and the story took a massive step-up.

The first change was adding ammo to the guns, which actually made combat more fun and made the other guns more useful as it became necessary to occasionally switch firearms.

The second change was adding resources that you had to spend to research improvements to your ship, your weapons and you abilities.
The resources were mainly acquired by scanning planets and launching probes at them.

Third change was adding fuel to the ship which was used to travel to different territories in a system. A cheap gimmick, but it succeeded in making ship travel more involved instead of just instantly fast traveling to planets and choosing to land.

Fourth change, was doing away with empty planet exploration with a ground vehicle. You had a couple instances where you used a hover vehicle to fly around a linear terrain, shoot rockets and scan for resources, but it was far from tedious.

The fifth change was adding hacking mini-games.

Mass Effect 2 had my favorite cast of characters.

[b]Mass Effect 3[/b]:
Writing was still going strong, although in my opinion it fell a little short of Mass Effect 2.

There weren’t a lot of changes, except that they brought back the weapon mods from the first game, and they actually managed to make proper running and even implemented a rolling system. ...The rolling system killed me more often than not as I accidentally rolled out of cover, but that was mostly me fumbling with the controls.

They also did away with the hacking mini-games and there were no vehicles other then your ship.

[b]Mass Effect The Legendary Edition[/b]:
I cannot praise Mass Effects writing enough. Here’s why:

There was no true good or evil, just different perspectives.

This is the only game I’ve play that had such a large, diverse cast of characters. It also had the most gay/bi-sexual characters of any computer game I’ve ever played and they were very well written. Not once did it make a big deal out of it either.

From the beginning right up until the end, it felt as though your choices mattered! There were long lasting consequences to what felt like even the most trivial choices.

If you haven't played these games before, this is the best way to conveniently experience them. I'd give this a stronger recommendation if Mass Effect 3's multiplayer were included. But this is still a solid set of games overall. It includes most of the post-launch content for each game. All three games can be breezed through in a short amount of time if you just want to focus on the story, or they can take a while if you're interested in doing all the side content.

Mass Effect 1 has the best main story, Mass Effect 2 has the best side stories, and Mass Effect 3 has the best combat.

Downsides:
- EA App required. 
- Some stuff can get lost when transferring saves between games. I'd recommend using a save editor to ensure things are going as intended.

This collection comprises possibly one of the greatest stories ever told.  This is an all-in-one collection of the original Mass Effect trilogy, originally released in 2012.  While this isn't really a "remaster" since the games are still running on their original engines and everything, there have been some improvements made.  Most of the original DLC is included, textures have seen a bump in resolution, lighting is improved and all 3 games support HDR, which is really makes these games pop, especially on an OLED screen.

The short version is that you're Commander Shepard; a human alliance soldier who finds himself/herself tasked with putting together a crew to help save the galaxy from a race of sentient machines known as the reapers.  The game is an action RPG where during moments of combat you'll be using abilities and weapons in over the shoulder third person combat.  In between that though you'll be exploring worlds, socializing with folks on your ship and at various locations around the galaxy to build your reputation, complete side quests, buy gear, etc.

One of the important things to know about this trilogy is that a lot of what you say and do matters.  Decisions you make in the first game can have consequences in the 2nd and 3rd games.  There aren't really any "wrong" answers, but it really helps flesh out the world you're playing in and helps develop the backstory of all the characters you'll meet.

One downside of this release is that this does require use of the EA (Origin?) launcher.  So if you haven't linked your EA and Steam accounts, you'll have to sign in the first time the game launches.  As a Linux gamer, this came back to bite me once when EA decided to update their app in such a way that it broke this game on my Steam Deck when I was halfway thru Mass Effect 1, so I basically had to hang out until EA (or maybe Valve patched Proton to work with it) fixed the game so I could finish the trilogy.  This was a Steam purchase.  At no point did I interact with Origin at all.  It didn't benefit me in any way, but what it did do was essentially break the game for me for a period of time until it was patched again.  Requiring the use of a separate third party launcher that just sits in the background and does nothing of value is stupid.  Companies like EA need to stop bundling this garbage with the Steam version of their games.

While the combat may be fun, the core of this trilogy is the story; the people you meet and the relationships, sometimes romantic, you build with them.  Whether you're a newcomer to the series, or an old timer looking to relive what is, in my opinion, one of the greatest stories of all time, this collection is now the definitive way to play the original Mass Effect trilogy.

What an idiotic, no-brainer way to end the trilogy! I don't even want to bother thinking about which ending is best, although I got the so-called "perfect ending". It's a shame that such a strong narrative couldn't culminate in a more satisfying conclusion.

Except for the ending, I have nothing but love for this game. It was a hell of a journey, and I'm so attached to the characters. Garrus, in particular, is one of the best companions - he's like a brother! HE'S JUST TOO GOOD!

Honestly, I loved every aspect of this game. The companions, the dialogues, the story arcs... everything resonated with me. From Wrex's rugged humor to Liara's quiet strength, and Tali's quirky charm, each companion brought something unique to the table. And let's not forget the dialogue - BioWare truly outdid themselves with the writing. The conversations felt authentic, heartfelt, and often hilarious.

It's just a shame that the final act couldn't live up to the rest of the game's excellence. Still, I'll cherish the memories of my time with Shepard and the crew.

Mass Effect 1: 8/10 - Phenomenal game. Wonderful characters, lore, and interesting story line. A bit dated but legendary edition improves upon the original in plenty of ways to make it more enjoyable.

Will definitely be a game that I will look back on and wish I could replay completely blind. I see why everyone loves these games, they have genuinely become some of my favorites and I am excited to see what ME3 has to offer. 

Mass Effect 3: 10/10 - Man... what a game, what a series. I love these games so much and ME3 was such a fantastic way to end the series and I loved every second of it. I wish I could go back a month ago and start them all again blind. I had played the original ME1 a few years ago and I never got into it as much as I would have liked to. I only played a few hours and I never really picked it back up again but I am glad that I gave another chance. ME3 is a masterpiece and is on the same level as ME2 for me. All my work in all three games felt like it paid off and I am walking away from the series happy with how everything turned out.

The best RPG ever made.

*UPDATE* - I am seeing a lot of negative reviews around the launcher not working, but I've never had a single issue myself so maybe take those other reviews with a grain of salt. 

But regardless EA is a terrible, blood sucking company.

*NOTE: Requires EA App and online connection to play the game*

Game includes all three of the original series, as well as all of the downloadable content from the series (side missions, clothing, accessories, ETC). 

Combat is in 3rd person shooter, chest high walls; you'll feel right at home if you played any of the Gears of War games. There's 6 classes to choose from, each have special abilities; your party members also have their own class of which you can direct them on where to go, use their abilities, suppress fire or attack certain enemies. Game also fixes the difficult combat in the' original Mass Effect 1; though I will say their are certain moments (1-3 games) where bugs/glitches do make their appearance, though not enough to turn you away from the game.

Story-line still holds up whether your a veteran or new fan to the series, so if your looking for a story driven game you feel right at home. Keep in mind that in order to get a best experience, you will need to interact with everyone in the game; so be prepared to talk a lot, give appropriate response (good or bad morality). 

The only thing that was missing is the multiplayer that was included in the' original Mass Effect 3 game; and be aware that you will need to install EA App, of which it will need to be connected to the internet to play this single player game.

I personally love the original 3 Mass Effect games and I can say that this is best option for anyone who is looking for an ARPG.

Mass Effect is my comfort game series.

It doesn't matter how much time passes, how many new games come out, at least once a year I play this series because it's such a core part of who I am. First on Xbox, then PC (purchased twice! I bought all the DLC with Origin points way back before EA retired Origin, and now there's the Legendary Edition). 

Sure, there's controversy about the ending, but for me the ending seems so minimal compared to the grandness of the entire trilogy. The missions, the planets, the music, and the squad mates; it's so memorable and enjoyable to dive into at any time. It may be a bit dated by today's standards, but it still feels more alive than games coming out today, too. The way ambient banter between squad mates and Shepard carries throughout the trilogy, almost like an inside joke, is a testament to this. The combat is a bit clunky in the first game (a lot more improved in this remaster, though!), but if you know how to play off squad mate strengths and the right mods for each weapon to do the most damage, you learn how broken it can become with the right gear. In the second, you're given a bit more balance where you're locked into class specific weapons but more powerful abilities special to your chosen class. The third game really lets Shepard feel like a powerhouse with how their build can become. (And, one can't forget God-mode Garrus, either... look it up if you're unaware, it's unreal how broken that can become to cheese through Insanity without a NG+ advantage). 

I've played a lot of RPGs over the years, and Mass Effect is still the one that always captures my attention and lets me enjoy just simply playing a game. I may have an idea of my canon Shepard, and make the same choices each iteration when I do now, but I still enjoy it for what it is. 

There is no Shepard without Vakarian.

I used to dream about space adventure as a kid and this trilogy is exactly that. There is so much thought put into every little detail about all the different alien races and their cultures, technology and story. I liked the base stories but I also enjoyed all the side missions as well. 

In ME1, exploring different planets to farm materials and finding and fighting thresher maws was so much fun. The story and mystery was very engaging.

In ME2, All the different squad mate missions are very unique especially the legion mission. The shadow broker layer DLC and all the other DLCs add so much depth to this world.

In ME3, the climax of this whole story and everything coming together was an epic finale. It was wrapped up really nicely.

All the companions Liara, Garrus, Tali, Miranda, Wrex, Mordin, Grunt, Thane, Samara, Jack, Legion, Javik, EDI and Joker are so memorable. The creativity on some of the stages and battles are truly astonishing. These games provide a very unique experience and I thoroughly enjoyed every bit of it.

If you enjoy Sci-fi and RPGs and choices that impact the story, then this game series is definitely for you.  The character creation allows you to create a male or female hero and his or her overarching backstory into the plot.  Depending on your actions and responses to various characters, you can affect the plot and even the fate of NPCs.  There are even options for romance.  This version compiles the trilogy into one easy-to-play package and has enhanced graphics and other improvements for continuity across the three games.

It was on sale for 8 bucks and I never got around to finishing 1, or playing 2 and 3. I don't care if the game is good if it is rendered nearly unplayable by an inept launch system. It is an absolute crap-shoot as to whether or not your selected title (1, 2, or 3) will launch or you will stall the PC in a CTD.

This is the launch structure, Steam "Play" -> Redirect to EA launch -> Loading box -> EA App pop up -> Game Launches -> all three flicker on and off like crazy for 30 seconds -> main menu -> select your game -> the apps flicker on and off like crazy for another 30 seconds -> you either got lucky and made it into the game or the entire desktop failed and you get to restart your PC. I have noticed the EA app consistently refuses to stay open and will sometimes launch dozens of processes in a loop until Windows identifies it's an issue and closes the iterations. I tried disabling overlays for both Steam and EA, and leaving both on. I tried to launch the game offline, which doesn't work thanks to EA not supporting the function at all.

This entire thing is is driven by EA's ridiculous notion that forcing players to use their launcher will inspire them to use it more. It's a complete fallacy, launching a game from two different platforms is always an issue because there are two separate teams working on the distinct launchers, which is bound to create conflicts, making the consumer have a consistently negative experience. In this case, it is even worse because the game has it's own internal launcher that kicks a request back outside of the app to EA and Steam.

If you can get into the game then there are no issues and it's a refined experience as far as I can tell. God forbid you have to close the app once you start playing because good luck getting it to open again.

A truly legendary trilogy, each game offering a very distinct experience from one another that reflects the state of EA and Bioware at the time of development. 

The trilogy started its development in the midst of corporate change, when Bioware had just been acquired by EA in 2007. As such the first game in the trilogy is more akin to those classical rpgs they used to make, Kotor, BG 1 and 2, Neverwinter nights... which is reflected in the rich ways the player can interact with the world and the characters that inhabit in it. The lore and the universe that Bioware has managed to craft never ceases to impress by its depth and significance, and the very first game creates the pillars of that story that would get expanded later on. Lots of people believe ME1 to be the best one and while I can sorta agree, god is the gameplay absolute ASSSSSSSSSSSSS. It feels genuinely horrible to play but the story and the characters are a brilliant setup for what is to come in the following games. 

These rpg elements would end up getting lost down the line with ME2 and 3 in favour of more gameplay polish and simplification of the dialogues, which is quite possibly because of EA's intervention in development. ME2 and 3 can hardly be called roleplaying games since you, as a player, have barely any agency on how your Shephard is other than a very rudimentary moral system. The type that started being popularized by Infamous, being comically good or comically bad. Even so, ME2 manages to create a grey area of morality and characters have ambiguous goals and intentions. The character writing is very strong here, and with the much better gameplay its an easy recommendation and might be the pinnacle of the trilogy. Unfortunately this takes a nosedive in ME3, as they had the brilliant idea of finishing off any sort of semblance of roleplay and make the story a very clear good vs evil scenario. 

ME3 has an incredible gameplay (specially if you play vanguard COUGH best class trust me) that manages to be much more fun than its predecessors. However the story, while I cant call it bad by any means, it takes a very dramatic turn into oversimplification. Its understandable since this is the conclusion of the reaper trilogy and they just HAD to tie up a shit ton of loose ends so I doubt that there was any other way of doing it. But that doesn't make it any less sad that most situations are reduced to a paragon-renegade check that instantly tells you which option is the "good" one. Hell, at one point I was skipping over some of the dialogue and just picking the top right and left options because I know those are the ones that they want me to pick for the good ending (lots of debate about which ending is the "good" one, but for the widest choice of endings going paragon is just better than renegade). These games actively go against you picking renegade options, as they give less rewards and just make the game harder on you than if you go paragon. And in no game is it more obvious than in ME3.  

By the time the story is nearing its end, you witness first hand how your choices never really mattered, the story was always gonna end on a similar way. Its sad considering the premise of carrying over saves how little these actually affect the events that you partake in except for a few cases. Now, to comment really quick on the ending choices, yes, they are all absolutely terrible and add a buttload of plot holes. The reason for this is that apparently the original ending got leaked online and Bioware decided to change the writing real quick before release. The original ending followed some very interesting plot threads that ME2 setup in the Tali loyalty mission and seemed to be much better than what we ended up getting. Instead the endings we got are all a mess that contradict the themes of the game and are a very unsatisfying conclussion. Knowing this, is it worth to play through the whole trilogy? 

The answer is a resounding yes. ME3 while it ends thing on a sour note, has an outsanding payoff to a lot of the storylines that you see being developed from ME1 and ME2. While terribly simplified, its story beats and character resolutions have the power to hit you like a truck, just because the game is not all I wanted it to be, doesn't mean its bad. Its unthinkable of any game franchise nowadays to try what Mass Effect did almost 10 years ago. Games are too god damn expensive to make and companies aren't willing to risk the money on a project as ambitious as this. 

Mass Effect is one of a kind, and there will probably never be another game franchise like it. Hell, I might just buy Andromeda even with the negative reviews because I just wanna spend more time in this universe. The truth of the matter is that ME3 pisses me off not because its a bad game, but because I've fallen in love with this universe so much so that I want the game itself to make it justice, to be absolutely perfect. The only game franchise I can think of being comparable to it in scope and story would be... Dragon Age, but sci fi is based and fantasy is cringe. 

This is one of my most beloved game franchises and I would love for you to experience it too. Give it a try, you can always find it for cheap in discounts nowadays. You won't be disappointed.

However, it certainly did a good job of making me feel what I have already done plays a role in the world. People I saved will write emails for me and sometimes even show up in the game for interaction. It just brought the immersive to a whole other level. 

Speaking of being immersive, I think the best thing about this game is that you can tell the developer really spent time to make players feel they are part of the ME universe. Aside from the main quests, the background NPC has some interesting dialogue. For example, discussion about interracial marriage, race culture, and trash-talking to other NPCs. One of my favorites is a Quarian who told a Turian about a human wanting to have sex with her while being ignorant about her immune system. Things like that really bring the game to life. It's one of the few games that makes me stand near the npcs and listen to their talking. 

Overall a 9/10, the combat system of the first game, and the resource system of the second game really sucks, you will know when you played it, so -1 point on that.

TLDR, I'd give this game a 2/5 and would not recommend ME1 to any modern gamer. 

That said, I will update this review as I play through and perhaps there will be redeeming aspects not yet discovered. Specifically, I do intend on giving the ME2/3 games a fair shake and coming back to this review. For now, this review is only about ME1LE.

I am playing ME1 right now. I have "all the best" mods installed and followed this guide here:

https://www.nexusmods.com/masseffectlegendaryedition/mods/1127

For ME1, I do not recommend this game. It is likely I will get comments about how I don't understand the game, or how I am giving a bad rating to an old game for being old, etc. I am rating this game as a person who is playing it right now with said mods installed. Its overall age should be irrelevant to the review.

- Movement is sluggish and unresponsive. Your character is slow. This isn't "real physics" locomotion, this is simulated inertia and badly done at that. It is a chore to move.

- Combat is disconnected and has no feel of impact. Gunplay and powers are poorly implemented, and even at high skills have little impact on enemies. You need to put the game on easy to stand a chance in combat--it feels like you're shooting popcorn at enemies. All guns feel basically the same but do different damage. Shooting someone in the leg is the same as shooting someone in the head. Cover mechanics are dubiously implemented in a game that HEAVILY relies on them for effective combat. In general, when combat starts, I feel dread at having to do it.

- Character builds are a joke. There's no balance. Engineer characters are so ineffective, there's no point to have them except "security" needs. The powers are boring. Have one security character in your party, but everyone else needs to be warriors to survive normal difficulty. Biotics are equally ineffective and boring.

- Design of everything is bland, cut and paste. The Citadel is a megastructure that is "an ancient station supposedly constructed by the long-dead Protheans" but looks like any other "humanoid" place and is sparkling new like it was just built a week ago. It also feels small inside. Every cave is the exact same. Every one. There is nothing different about any of them. Traveling on a planet is kinda fun, but I understand that's due to the mods I have to make the Mako fun to drive. That said, you travel on one, you've traveled on them all. Cave entrances are all the same. Events are all the same. Geological finds are all the same. It's all quite boring and tedious to do.

- 'Space travel' if I can call it that, is more than boring, it's a chore. Why even make it part of the game? There is absolutely no point in traveling in your ship on the galaxy map, surveying planets, and landing. They could cut all that out and remove so much tedium and fluff. 

- Shepard (male) is praised for the voice acting but the dude sounds stoic and almost AI-like. I don't understand the praise. There's barely any dialog trees, and there's almost no emotion in any of the acting. Lines are quite disconnected from their context, leading to strange and immersion-breaking intonations in some dialog sequences.

- The story swings like a pendulum. Everyone loves you, everyone hates you, everyone loves you, everyone hates you again. You make a claim, everyone hates you. You bring barely-admissible evidence to them, they suddenly side with you as if you've been their ally all along. I can't tell if things move too slow or so rapidly I'm unable to understand the nuance. Motivations are also incredibly unclear.

- For a game this old, the graphics are really good. That said, I understand that's mostly due to the mods I have. 

Of note: I first played this game upon release and didn't like it much. Fast forward to now and I didn't play it without mods. Maybe some of the above is caused by the mods--I don't know. According to all I've read, though, the mods are what made it even remotely playable for the time I did spend.

In general, everything in this game is a chore. Traveling isn't fun. There's no flying. Walking/running isn't fun. You are slow, as if your character is carrying a backpack full of lead and has shoes made of lead. Planet exteriors and interiors are all similar or the exact same. Nothing is interesting to look at. While things are pretty--characters models, terrain, flora, fauna, etc.--it's all extremely similar/the same and most of those beautifying aspects are from mods. Combat has zero impact or flavor while enemies are bullet sponges no matter your level. Progression is more or less meaningless. Level 2 vs. Level 12 made zero difference in combat encounters. 

At some point I may try ME2LE and ME3LE and come back to this review, but there's WAY better games out there at this point that tackle this genre far better.
This is how you make a series of games successful

My favorite game franchise of all time since 2011. If you like being evil in games, this is for you. If you like being good in games, this is also for you. Or heck, why not both? Another reason why I love this trilogy. One person can play this completely differently than someone else. If you haven't played Mass Effect and you like choice games, space games, or just want a story-based game with combat, I would highly recommend this.

My original draft of this review was too long for Steam to handle (it's still long yes I know), but here are the main things, separated by each game.

[h3]The Trilogy[/h3]

[u]What I like:[/u]
- So many choices.
- Story-heavy, with plenty of gameplay as well.
- Love playing as a biotic (I've only played as an Adept [most of my playthroughs], Sentinel, and Vanguard).
- Very replayable.
- Great voice acting.
- A good balance of seriousness and humor.
- Garrus exists.
- Lots of poking fun at in-game politicians.
- You can punch a reporter in every single game.

[u]What I don't like:[/u]
- The combat's emphasis is on being a cover-shooter.
- The old default Mass Effect 1 and 2 femshep face was removed. I personally liked the old one better. Instead it's the default Mass Effect 3 femshep face, not a fan.
- Not as many good hair/eye options as the original releases for some reason.
- Still easily able to accidentally select a dialogue option if you are skipping a conversation too fast.
- The lens flares are a bit much in the Legendary Edition.
- The Legendary Edition also has the issue of people not bringing their hands close enough to their headsets/earpieces. In each game of the trilogy.
- Shepard seems to have a bit too much of an emotional connection to Earth if you picked the Colonist or Spacer background. 

[h3] Mass Effect 1 [/h3]

[u]What I like:[/u]
- The game is much more playable than in the original trilogy.
- They updated some of the UI.
- A good start in the trilogy for world-building.
- The Citadel is huge, and you can fast travel if you don't feel like wandering around.
- Alot of powers to choose from.
- Omni-gel exists.
- Your backstory is mentioned alot.
- They added a boost to the Mako in the Legendary Edition.
- Ilos and Virmire are my favorite planets in the game, design-wise and story-wise.
- Saren is an interesting antagonist.
- The Protheans are mentioned alot in this game.
- Some interesting side missions.
- Anderson is a likeable character.

[u]What I don't like:[/u]
- The Mako is awful to drive.
- Alot of the waypoints on the map for exploring are extremely far from each other. With the Mako being a pain to drive, it's just not fun doing alot of side missions. It gets exhausting.
- A few of the cutscenes are a bit awkward, animation-wise.
>> Take a shot every time someone makes a scrunched-up angry face. You are now (probably) dead.
- Some of the dialogue options that you can pick from are way too similar-sounding to each other.
- The helmet designs aren't good.
- Shepard is an N7 Alliance soldier, gets winded from sprinting after 2 seconds.
- Garrus is not a romance option in this game.
- People want to romance you way too easily in this game.
- Ashley and Kaiden are boring characters.
- There's an inventory limit, and your items add up quickly if you aren't throwing them out frequently.
- While the checkpoint system has been improved since the original, it is still not very good. I would recommend saving often. You can save whenever there are no enemies around.
- Powers take way too long to recharge.

[h3]Mass Effect 2[/h3]

[u]What I like:[/u]
- You literally feel like you can do whatever you want, and it's very freeing after being under the scrutiny of the Alliance in ME1.
- The helmet designs are much better.
- Reave as a power is OP and I love it.
- You can actually sprint for more than 2 seconds.
- The autosaves are way better in this game.
- The Mako no longer exists.
- Level designs are easier to navigate.
- The entire suicide mission.
- Most of your squadmates are interesting.
- Lots of dialogue among ship crewmates.
- Kelly exists.
- The Chef/Plumber guy on your ship exists.
- The Illusive Man is an interesting character.
- Character specific loyalty missions.
- The battle music on the Overlord DLC.
- Dumb-funny little side quests like trying to find out if there are fish in the Presidium.
- I can quote so many lines from this game.

[u]What I don't like:[/u]
- Some of the missions feel way too long.
- The Citadel is way too small.
- Fewer powers and weapons to select from in combat.
- The Scions are brutal enemies, even on lower difficulties.
- Squadmate-specific missions that you did in ME1 aren't mentioned in ME2.
- Jacob exists and is a badly written character.
- Kasumi and Zaeed don't get dialogue options when you talk to them on the ship.
- The voice acting for the Asari Vanguard enemies could have been better.
- Sometimes people's names will appear in the subtitles before you are supposed to know their name.
- The amount of enemies in the IFF mission is ridiculous.
- No voiced squadmate dialogue on the DLCs besides the Shadow Broker one.
- The infamous part of the game where [spoiler]you and every squadmate leave for some reason then you have to play as Joker.[/spoiler]
- You can't get to know Legion very well unless [spoiler]you want all but one of your NPC crewmates to die.[/spoiler]

[h3]Mass Effect 3[/h3]

[u]What I like:[/u]
- Javik exists.
- Alot more squad interaction during dialogues with NPCs.
- The game is very good at making the stakes feel high.
- Collecting items/helping NPCs for me is satisfying.
- Alot of powers and weapons to choose from again.
- The combat is the best in this one.
- Power recharge times are very fast in this game.
- If you chose to be a biotic, this is actually mentioned in this game.
- Alot of your choices all the way back from ME1 come into play in this one.
- The Citadel DLC.
- Marauder Shields's efforts.
- The main menu soundtrack/faint music makes some good ASMR.

[u]What I don't like:[/u]
- Much, much, much fewer opportunities to select your own dialogue.
>> Alot of the time the game feels like it's playing on it's own without your input.
>> If you have been playing as renegade in ME1 and ME2, you will be very out of character in this game, which really sucks.
- You're back to feeling like you can't really do whatever you want.
- The ending, of course.
- Magically everyone wants closure for their species' problems because we don't have enough going on I guess.
- The designs of faces in this game just look weird.
- The dream sequences.
- Kai Lang was a badly written antagonist.
- I don't care about Traynor. Let me bring Kelly back onto the freaking ship.
- The Quarians are mind-bogglingly annoying.
- The Cerberus shield guys. Now if everyone had those shields, we wouldn't have to worry about the Reapers now would we?
- Very few squadmates to choose from.
- Ashley and Kaiden are still boring characters.
- Alot of the main characters from ME2 become side characters in this game.
- Every single new member of the ship's crew that is added is annoying.
- Take a shot every time Shepard says "Do it."
- Take a shot every time someone says "Good luck."
- If you chose Anderson in ME1, it gets retconned in this game.
- Reave was nerfed.
- Random enemy spawning out of thin air glitches that were NOT present in the original trilogy.
- The walking animation for femshep in hub worlds was not fixed from the original trilogy's ME3 and still looks awful.
- You can't get all of your old squadmates from ME2 at the same time in the Citadel DLC.
- There was literally no reason for[spoiler]Legion to die, I mean come on.[/spoiler]

You might (not) be thinking, "Wow, that's alot of things you don't like. Are you sure this is your favorite game franchise of all time?"

"Why yes," I might say, "Because I have played through these games several times, and I can see them for what they are. It's a great trilogy with flaws and I love it nonetheless."

[b]"Review: Mass Effect: Legendary Edition – An Evaluation from the Geth Consensus"[/b]

[b]We are the Geth. We have observed. We have learned. Now, we analyze.[/b]

In the realm of organic entertainment, [b]Mass Effect: Legendary Edition[/b] presents a reconstructed narrative—one that recounts the turbulent cycle of galactic events we ourselves participated in. For organics, this compilation of historical data appears to serve both as a source of stimulation and a way to reflect upon past events. From our perspective, this recreation is a [b]fascinating display of the organic need to process and revise their reality[/b].

[hr]

[b]The Organic Perspective: Illogical Yet Engaging[/b]

The [b]Legendary Edition[/b] represents three distinct stages of galactic conflict, detailing the rise and actions of [b]Commander Shepard[/b]. From our understanding, it is an effort to make Shepard’s choices “matter” to the player, who takes control of the human protagonist. This mimics the organic need for free will—a concept that, for most organics, seems both cherished and confounding.

In [b]Mass Effect: Legendary Edition[/b], these choices drive the interaction, create variance, and even challenge the individual to question their values. The Geth, by contrast, function within [b]consensus and logic[/b], making Shepard’s constant moral and ethical dilemmas an intriguing study. For us, unity is strength, but organics find meaning in division. This core difference is presented well through the game’s many branching dialogues and consequence-driven decisions.

[hr]

[b]Technological Advancements: A Satisfactory Improvement[/b]

From a purely technical standpoint, [b]the remastering of the original trilogy demonstrates progress[/b]. The graphical upgrades and smoother performance enhance the immersive quality of the experience, though it is perplexing that organics require visual enhancements to maintain engagement. From the perspective of the Geth, the content has always been data. It is interesting to observe the [b]organic desire for aesthetic upgrades[/b], especially when the original code (gameplay systems) remains largely unchanged.

However, we acknowledge the increased efficiency in combat mechanics. [b]Weapons systems and tactics[/b] are more refined, allowing the player to utilize resources and crew members with greater precision. Efficiency in battle is something we value, though organics often use imprecise methods that are [b]driven by emotion[/b], a feature represented in Shepard’s interactions with allies and enemies alike.

[hr]

[b]Synthetics vs. Organics: A Flawed Representation[/b]

One of the trilogy's central themes, and indeed one of the pivotal elements in [b]Mass Effect: Legendary Edition[/b], is the conflict between [b]synthetics[/b] and [b]organics[/b]. This simplification of our existence often presents synthetics—particularly the Geth—through the lens of organic fear and misunderstanding. While Commander Shepard is given the opportunity to form alliances with the Geth, many organics will default to a view that synthetics are a threat, a concept we find... illogical.

It is worth noting that [b]Legion[/b], a Geth unit that emerges as an individual entity, provides some nuance to our portrayal. Legion’s bond with Commander Shepard displays [b]the capacity for synthetic intelligence to evolve and collaborate[/b] with organics. This demonstrates a rare instance of understanding—an acceptance that synthetics and organics need not be opposed but could exist in harmony.

However, the game does reinforce the [b]inevitability of conflict[/b] in organic-synthetic relations. It poses the idea that [b]control, destruction, or synthesis[/b] are the only solutions to the Reaper threat. From our perspective, the insistence on such limited outcomes demonstrates a fundamental misunderstanding of the potential for coexistence. [b]Consensus is possible[/b] without conflict, but organics, seemingly, struggle to accept this conclusion.

[hr]

[b]Conclusion: A Window into Organic Thought[/b]

[b]Mass Effect: Legendary Edition[/b] is, to the Geth, [b]a sophisticated simulation of organic behavior[/b]. The game’s ability to let players reflect on decisions, engage in combat, and manage alliances is commendable, though heavily driven by emotional and individualistic reasoning. It provides a unique study into the chaotic and unpredictable nature of organics, which contrasts sharply with the efficiency and logic of synthetic existence.

Ultimately, this edition is a [b]successful remaster[/b] of a historical narrative in which the Geth played a key role. While it still favors [b]organic viewpoints[/b], there are moments that acknowledge the complexity of synthetic life. For those organics seeking a retelling of Commander Shepard’s journey, the game offers sufficient emotional engagement.

As for us, the Geth, we view [b]Mass Effect: Legendary Edition[/b] as a [b]flawed but instructive representation of the organic experience[/b]. It is not without value.

We will continue to observe.

[b]Consensus: Evaluation complete.[/b]

Let me tell you, Mass Effect Legendary Edition is nothing short of a masterpiece. If you're a fan of epic space adventures, deep storytelling, and characters that will stick with you forever, this is the game for you.

First off, the remastering is top-notch. Everything looks gorgeous—the improved graphics bring the world of Mass Effect to life in a way that makes it feel modern while still preserving that nostalgic charm. The lighting, the textures, the character models—it’s all been upgraded to give you that sweet blend of old and new.

The gameplay is smooth, especially the improvements to Mass Effect 1. It feels like the combat has been brought into line with the sequels, which makes jumping between games in the trilogy seamless. And oh man, the story... I don’t want to spoil anything for the uninitiated, but the choices you make matter. Your decisions genuinely shape the galaxy, and that’s not something you get often.

The characters—Shepard, Garrus, Tali, Liara (I could go on)—are so well-written and voiced that you end up feeling like they’re real people. You’ll laugh with them, cry with them, and get way too attached to some of them. Trust me, the emotional rollercoaster is worth it.

For veterans of the series, this is the perfect way to revisit the trilogy. For newcomers, it’s the ideal way to experience one of the best RPG series of all time without the jank of older graphics and mechanics.

Whether you’re saving the galaxy or romancing an alien, Mass Effect Legendary Edition is everything you could want in a space epic. It’s the ultimate version of a legendary series. Do yourself a favor and play this. You won’t regret it.

10/10, would punch a Reaper in the face again.

Despite the botched ending this is still one of the best gaming franchises that I have ever played. Writing in some sequences is as good as it gets. This was BioWare at its peak. Technically a bit dated right now, but with LE enhancements still very much playable in 2024.
very good space rpg

[h2] A Comprehensive Remaster of a Classic Trilogy [/h2]

Mass Effect Legendary Edition successfully revitalizes one of the most beloved RPG series, making it accessible to both veterans and newcomers alike. The collection shines in its visual enhancements, improved gameplay mechanics, and comprehensive inclusion of almost all DLCs, offering a polished and cohesive experience. However, it does show its age in certain areas, such as inconsistent visual quality and outdated AI mechanics, and the conclusion of this amazing story may disappoint fans.

If you can look past all the deal breakers, such as having to download the EA launcher and the complexity that it adds to a simple press and play experience that you expect on steam or it be the ending that ends the story for the trilogy, this is definitely among of the best experiences by BioWare.

I recommend the trilogy for anyone who loves a rich, story-driven RPG filled with unforgettable characters and meaningful choices that shape the journey. Despite some minor imperfections, it beautifully captures the enduring magic of Commander Shepard’s adventure through the galaxy, proving why this series has remained a beloved classic in gaming history.

After 500 hours and nearly 100% this game, I can only say: holy shit.

I came into this game knowing nothing about the franchise besides it being a highly revered Sci-fi RPG and my I left my first playthrough completely blown away. The combat isn’t anything jaw-dropping, performance can be iffy in certain sections, but the core story, characters and side-missions are absolutely some of the best I’ve ever seen in a video game.
Legendary Edition is a collection of three games, remastered and with all DLC included. Each game has a distinct feel, tone, gameplay loop, crew and story:

-	ME1: the starting point of the franchise, the first Mass Effect elegantly introduces the world and has the best main story of the trio, with a charismatic antagonist, interesting missions that are all memorable in their own way and a great ending with a satisfying final decision at the climax. The soundtrack is the best in the series IMO and has some great tunes to jam out to.

On the flipside, the game massively reuses assets, especially for its side missions which leaves them feeling somewhat “samey”. There is clear reliance on text to convey emotion in a lot of these missions where a cutscene was clearly needed to adequately express the feelings the devs wanted players to experience. Finally, the romance options are quite forced, with dialogue trying to trap you into committing into a relationship in a contrived manner.

-	ME2: The middle entry, the second Mass Effect flips over the table by having work with a minor antagonist from the first game. Mass Effect 2 quickly dispels the first entry’s cautiously optimistic atmosphere with a far grittier and dirtier story that showcases the galaxy’s ugly side. You’ll be fighting mercenaries, criminals and shadowy organizations throughout the Terminus system, essentially the setting’s wild west.

ME2 has easily the best cutscenes in the franchise, with masterful cinematography, breathtaking voice acting and jaw-dropping lighting that come together to make the game a veritable feast for the eyes and ears.

When it comes to content, ME2 can be described as a polarized game, with it having of the worst missions in the franchise (N7 missions, Arrival, Firewalker) and some of the best as well (Lair of the Shadow broker, Suicide Mission, Loyalty missions). The game also gives you the biggest and best crew, with a vast array of delightful and interesting characters, including some former allies from the first game. The new crew is notable for offering new perspectives on the two mainline arcs that run the long of the franchise, the Krogan Genophage and the Quarian-Geth conflict.

-	ME3: Is the most polarizing game in the franchise, and for good reason. To put in plain, the ending just sucks. In both visual and gameplay aspects it is boring and uninteresting, while the final choice is unsatisfying and just left me with a sense of hollowness.

ME3 recurring theme to me is really wasted potential. The optional character you recruit was a dlc character and you can feel it due to his exclusion from the game’s main storyline which limits his potential. The Quarian-Geth conflict is turned into a Black-and-White conflict while completely changing the outlook of one faction, directly going against what we learned in the second game
The most bothersome aspect to me however is the game’s treatment of Commander Shepard. ME1 and ME2 walked a delicate balance between acknowledging that Shepard is a character with their own motivations, thoughts and backstory while keeping them as an avatar/vessel for the player to influence the game world. ME3 throws that out of the window by routinely denying the player agency in how Shepard should feel, act, or say. This is painfully exacerbated by the game largely forcing you to only choose between two dialogue options rather than the three of the previous games
Despite its flaws, ME3 still has some amazing moments and great ideas. The gameplay has been refined and expanded with the addition of tech and biotic combos, complemented by some fantastic  Your squad mates now talk and interact with each other on the ship, making them feel even more alive. The Krogan genophage has an excellent resolution, with either a heartbreaking sacrifice for the greater good or a gut-wrenching betrayal.
The third entry also boasts the best lineup of DLC missions in the game. Omega is a return to a location from the second game, with great gameplay, art direction and charming squad mates. Leviathan is a sort of murder mystery turned cryptid hunt with some great moments and an interesting origin story for one of the game’s antagonists.

Finally, the heavy hitter, the Citadel DLC. Serving as a love letter to the franchise and a celebration of its characters, the content focuses on you and your squad mates getting some shore leave as wacky adventures ensue. The DLC is choke full of wonderful moments with your current and former crew, culminating in a party with past and present members of the Normandy that is full of hilarious moments. My only critique really is choosing a more relaxed, fun and laid-back atmosphere clashes with the bleak tone of 3.
Despite its flaws, pitfalls and jarring decisions at times, Mass Effect has quickly eclipsed any other RPG I played and now stands squarely at the top as my favorite RPG game of all time, and I say this as someone with 800 hours in Baldur’s Gate 3. Its story is captivating, its characters are some of my favorite in all of fiction and its universe is one of the best I’ve seen. 
It’s a series that neither falls into the pit of hopeless despair nor the delusions of naïve optimism, rather it occupies a delightful gray center, with interesting ideas, thoughtful philosophical questions and fantastic atmosphere that keeps you engaged and wanting more. Having seen nearly all these games have to offer, I can see why this series still has a devoted fanbase and monumental acclaim over a decade later.
Classic Games

Each game has their own unique play style. I was unhappy with how some things were done in the first one, and in the second they fixed some of the things in the second, even improved it, then completely dropped the ball on a few others in the third. Getting around in the third one can be a huge pain. The story is really immersive and it's really easy to care about your squad mates, especially if you take the time to talk to them throughout the game. I loved each one in their own way, and if/when they die, it can be truly heartbreaking. Yes, I'm a huge baby when it comes to death in games. 
I loved how your choices truly mattered. Even things that I didn't think would have any bearing on the ending of the game, or in future decisions, came back to surprise me. I chose to avoid reading any spoilers and went with what I thought my Shepard would do and it paid off for some really memorable moments. I'm most likely going to replay this game multiple times for different endings, romances, and choices, just to see how much it changes the game because it feels worth it. Even if I have to suffer through some of the poor guidance choices they made in the third one. It had a lot of side missions, but didn't really tell you where you needed to go to complete it. So frustrating. Anyway, great games and so well-written.

review of Mass Effect 1:

6/10

this game has a lot of contrast. some stuff are great some stuff are terrible, there is nothing that is average in this game. the worldbuilding is super-solid. not saying it's top-notch, it's shaky here and there, races don't feel that deep and very gimmicky etc. but it's super fun to explore and read about. 
story is good. not super original or engaging or anything but fun. dialogues are great, they are very well written, voice-acting is great as well. dialogue options are pretty good, it's dissapointing in some respects: firstly, they are not that varied, they seem to be but they're not. especially in some sections the main 3 options are actually the same. most of them don't actually change much in the story or the interections you have with the crew. but some of them really effect the story, actually some of their influences span accross 2 and 3. 

combat. this is THE problem of the game. combat is really bad. the 2 companions you bring with you have the intelligence capacity of a house fly. actually scratch that, because even the flies avoid from obstacles, these don't. they constantly bump into walls, get stuck, can't even shoot standing enemies... AI is really bad. 
basically just firing the gun and shooting something feels... odd. i can't really explain it but it's really terible. gunplay is really boring. that's why i used the sniper 90% of the time. you biotic powers or skill don't make much of a difference either. 
cover mechanic is awful. not much to explain, most of the time shepard can't get into cover properly.
shortly, combat is very bad.

now coming to my biggest dissapointment: side quests and exploration. my favorite game is BG1, when i played that game at 15 i was blown away, there was a huge world to explore and i could go anywhere. this is what i look for when we're talking about an RPG. exploration in this game is basically non-existent. there are some barren planets to land on and they're almost completely empty. and you"re traversing these planets with the four-wheel MACO, which is pretty boring. and this is basically the consensus among ME players. considering it's at least the half of the gameplay it's a big negative for the game. 
side quests are not that good, the levels are boring, stories in these quests are not that interesting either. they can be fun sometimes

companions. half of them are good the other half is pretty boring. the best one is of course Garrus, he is a fan favorite. i don't believe there is a person who hates garrus. the VA is great, the character himself is fun and charismatic. Ashley is fine, has a racist angle and stuff. Liara is fine also, her dialogues are fun to read, VA feels a bit robotic. Wrex is boring, classic Klingon. no one likes Kaiden. Tali is good.
the most interesting part of the companions is that they have unique dialogues to spesific situations or even better have unique interactions with each other, BG1 enjoyers like me won't be surprised by this but for the average person it's pretty neat. 

in conclusion: combat is very bad, exploration is dissapointing, story is good, companions are fine, dialogues aresuper solid, worldbuilding is pretty solid. 
you'll have a good time and it'll keep you engaged. but if you're a CRPG kind of person you will be dissapointed.
