~ME1~
Pros:
Good remaster overall. Performs fine at max settings on my 1440p ultrawide. Minor stuttering in the vehicle at times but wasn't that bad.
Awesome voice acting with some recognizable actors. The female Shepard was perfect, tough and no-nonsense, which really fits the character.
Music was nice too for the theme of the game. Sound effects were pretty good.
Nice storytelling. I enjoyed the dialogue and the intensity of the story presentation as well as the ending.

Cons:
Terrible face sculpting, many characters have a permanent look of surprise. Game is showing its age but even some older games had better character design.
There are some idle animations to keep things lively but for the most part, everyone stands around with the same stiff/rigid demeanor.
Not a great shooter. There is no ammo management as all guns have magical infinite ammo and instead you manage their heat levels.
All bodies magically disappear when killed. Presumably because this was a console title.
Also related to this being a console game first...this has a horrific UI with little to no information being presented on screen at any one time.
Awful AI, the melee opponents often run in circles. Enemies with guns will run right up to your crew and stand in the middle of everyone while trying to shoot you point blank. Allies will run in front of you constantly. If you order them to go to a position, sometimes they do it, sometimes they don't, and they never stay there long.
Level design is very boring. Just your basic empty hallways, copy/pasted rooms with minimal detail/clutter.
Vehicle controls are abhorrent. Press W to move forward but if you look behind you then W goes backwards? Makes no sense.
Character can't sprint for more than about 2-3 seconds.
Audio sliders only affect the gameplay so the cutscenes were WAY louder than I wanted.
Looter shooter where you constantly pick up 100 different weapons to replace that of yours and the crew.

Overall not a bad game but definitely not a great one. On its own, I would still recommend it for the story alone.

~ME2~
Pros:
Massive improvements overall. Better face sculpting, ammunition in favor of heat mgmt, improved AI, significantly better level design, terrific sound effects and voice acting as well as storytelling. The story is vastly more entertaining the way you go around recruiting your crew. The intricacy of the characters and how each has their own unique side quests really makes the game shine.
You can import your save so your character looks the same and all decisions made in the previous game are part of the sequel.
No longer a looter shooter as you have specific weapons and instead focus on upgrading them instead of replacing them.
Depending on paragon/renegade levels, you can interrupt others during dialogue and change the outcome of a scene. This is actually really interesting and fun, I wish more games did this.
With more character involvement and backstory, you really see how unique each alien race is in terms of their speech patterns and culture etc.

Cons:
Still terrible at sprinting, awful UI, they replaced the vehicle with a hovercraft thing that you platform with which is arcadey and doesn't belong.
Bodies still disappear and while they did add ammo mgmt, all the small caliber weapons use the same ammo which is fully replenished when picking up ammo.
They did away with crouching and using grenades for some reason

Overall an amazing game and one of the better RPGs I've played. Worth it for the story alone but the gameplay is vastly improved too.

~ME3~
Pros:
They added grenades back in and this time they are traditional throwables which is nice.
You can sprint forever!
Still has a great story and quality voice acting. I was literally in tears at the end. I truly enjoyed this experience.

Cons:
The dialogue seems a bit silly and even cringy at times. It is slightly less 'serious' than the first 2 games when doing side quests. Also, WAY TOO MUCH TIME is spent doing 'shore leave' stuff which takes away from the intensity of how serious the situation is in this story.
Can no longer holster a weapon. When you are in a combat area, you are constantly running around with weapon drawn and stuck in a tightly narrowed FOV.
The journal is much worse, there is less info and it rarely tells you where to go or what step you are at within the quest. You could have the item you need to fetch and not even know it. You might know you need to return an item to the Citadel but you'll have zero indication of which floor to go to.
No more probing planets for materials or minigames for hacking/bypass - this may be a Pro to some but a Con for others. Instead you probe a planet to acquire an item for a fetch quest and don't even leave the ship. I can understand removing hacking/bypass minigames for doors you NEED to go through, but removing them from things that would just grant you credits is just making it needlessly easy.

Overall not as good as ME2 on the whole but but still an awesome game with a spectacular set of endings. I loved it at the end and was genuinely in tears.

As a trilogy, I highly recommend it. This is a great series and I'm happy I finally got into it!

"Mass Effect Legendary Edition" revitalizes the classic trilogy with enhanced graphics and quality-of-life improvements but can be quite complicated, especially for newcomers. The intricate plotlines, vast universe, and multitude of character interactions can be overwhelming, making it difficult to grasp the full scope of the story and the impact of your choices. While the remastered visuals and streamlined gameplay mechanics are impressive, the depth of the lore and the complexity of relationships can leave players confused. For those unfamiliar with the original games, the learning curve may feel steep, making it challenging to fully appreciate the epic narrative and emotional stakes involving Commander Shepard and their crew. Despite these complexities, many fans still find the experience rewarding—but it's essential to approach the game with patience and an open mind.

[h1] ME trilogy review [/h1]

[u] Writing this on all-nighter brain [/u]

[h2] ME1 [/h2]

I had no idea what Mass Effect played like so I was quite surprised, purely on gameplay ME1 has a very solid, enjoyable experience.
Then you had the wonderful cast of characters, their stories, their banter and you just get hooked. There were some bumps which is expected from a game this old but honestly I would have prefered some of the aspects not to have as much in the sequels, and that I could romance Varrus in ME1 >:C

[h2] ME2 [/h2]
The continuation from ME1 story wise is *interesting*, felt a bit comedic at times but mixed appropriatly. Being able to take your character through the games is something I didn't know I valued so much and makes the story feel a lot more impactful, altough I quite liked in the companions in ME1, ME2 just went crazy, having characters from the first game both join your party and add a lot more species variety, which sets up great groundwork for ME3, the side characters also got a lot more development which was both much deserved and needed for the sequel story wise. Setup for the Illusive man was pretty great too, made me want to punch him for two whole games. Suicide mission was the perfect climax also.

[h2] ME3 [/h2]
Stakes as high as they get story wise, made me very happy I didn't lose a squad member in the suicide mission because I really don't know how the hell half of the plotlines would unfold, great characters got amazing ends to their storylines and you get the whole galaxy together.

The ending however I didn't quite like, which is fine, I'm more of appreciating the journey than the finale. And what a journey. Amazing 10/10

So far these might be the worst boss fights I every seen. Havent finished the game yet and will update later. Each side mission is so similar, it feels the same. Playing Mass Effect one.
 I played it before but never got past level 5. Now that it is upgraded, I wanted to see what the first game is about. So far I think its decent. The game throws a lot of information and mechanics at you. All of it I would say is decent or better. I did have to look up controls several times and some quest guides as the hints are terrible. Another reason I wanted to play the first one, I know your decisons carry over to the next game, something I only seen in Mass Effect. I want to call this game great but after 9 hours, nothing seems original. I think what gets me is the sheer amount of options this game has. Im still on the first one. Almost right at the get go, the amount of choices you can make that make big impact is insane. 

Really the best part of the game is the conversations. Its basically a big budget visual novel. As a Warhammer 40k fan, Im picking the jerk who works with aliens but will sacrifice them if needed. What sucks is the people all feel one note but the aliens feel natural. Anyways if you read this then yes I do recommend it. It is a long and not a easy game so you do need skill and time and make choices. If you can do all that, then you should play it.

Mass Effect 2,
Second Update
Beat the game at 46 and a half hours. Much longer than the first one. Most of that time was in resource collecting and conversations. The game makes many improvements over the first game but I do have many problems with it. That said I really enjoyed the ending and was just blown away how many things affected the ending. Its one of the smartest games I ever played. I do want to mention that the mini games get old quick and the vechile missions might be even worse than the first game. Its not perfect by any means. All the missions rewards are less than you find exploring. Even hacking a hard lock gets you a tiny reward. While I do have many many issues with the game, I do think its much better than most things on the market. I was able to one shot the final boss with the nuke launcher and that felt amazing. One issue I want to mention is most of the classes are light classes and the boss fights are really difficult even when you know the weakness. Some characters you gather end up being near pointless but they are fun to talk too. Another issue is I personally didnt find any of the characters attractive. You have to spend an insane amount of time with that character to unlock their scene which is why Im bringing it up. The romance scenes are also easy to lock if you dont have a guide. I ended my playthrough with about a 50/50 on good evil choices. Some of them are questionable. One good choice ends with a kill. There are other moments that are head scratchers. One other thing I want to mention is the with this edition, the starting weapons and armor are just as good if not better than the final ones you can unlock. I want out of my way to search for better stuff only for it to equal my starting weapon. Now each class makes a certain weapon better, mine was sniper rifles. I chose a sniper playthrough mostly cuz of the large rooms you fight in. I dont think I ever got a one shot with the weapon even fully maxed out. Heavy weapon ammo is so rare you never use it. One thing that did annoy me is time between missions matter and you get punished for messing around. This is a 40 hour plus game. Thats dumb. I have many many more issues with the game but I did buy for 10 dollars and I think it was worth it. It is a amazing game. Both this and the first one. 

Update
This is after 20 more hours. Not perfect but it is way better than Mass Effect 1 in almost every way. The only thing that really bugs me is any millitary choice gives bad karma which is werid and the main enemy has something called barriers and I dont have any counters for it. I have counters for everything except that. It is a much faster story than 1. The levels are a lot shorter, usually about 3 fights, and jam packed with new info. While the levels are shorter, the game has taken much more time to complete. I havent beat it yet. Just exploring now. Im playing the dlc and have mix feelings on them. The acting and new characters are great but the all the new ideas are not that good. Im glad its optional and not part of the main story. Another issue im having is everything seems to be more simple. I get Mass Effect univierse is complicated and theyre a lot to keep track of but the game being so simple is starting to wear me out. Its not feeling new anymore. While I enjoy the action, I kinda wish Mass Effect was just one big visual novel instead. The writing is easily the best thing about the series. 


So far its a lot more interesting. I enjoy every change except for maybe the combat. Its a shame the characters in the first game feel more like cameos than actual characters. I wouldnt mind exploring them more. Both games are similar where the main story is short but theyre a crazy amount of side content. I noticed not only did my choices carry over, I did not do every mission in one, My money and even material carried over. In one, material was only good for making money. In this, Material feels more important than stores. I havent explored much or done much side content. I wanted to a little stronger in case its high level missions. I do think the new crew and ship is a lot better and more interesting but it does lose that adventure feel and charm the first one had. Still the changes are so big, Im not sure if I could ever play the first one again. The new weapon types are also a nice touch. Ammo for them is rare. if you dont upgrade all the time, it might not even be possible to win. I think thats one annoying thing about this game. Its got tons and tons of choices, but its clear that you need some of these to even survive. In a long list of choices, some of them feel forced. I only just started playing 2 so I dont know how big the impact of you choices yet. My other issue is armor is so much wose in this game. I dont know why they nerfed in it into the ground. Every enemy does damage to you which is silly as your armor is pretty much diamonds with a diamond force field with diamond skin. But sure bullets hurt you. Even though your basically one big diamond. Now your team mates are mostly just normal guys so them getting one shotted is fine with me.

One of the finest experiences gaming has to offer, though it's not perfect. The Citadel was a boring start to the first game, which turned a lot of new players away from the franchise early on, the endings were controversial for good reason (though it's not as bad as many have been lead to believe, and has been improved on since the initial controversy), and Kai Leng is annoying and has plot armor a mile thick.

Despite all of these faults, I still consider the franchise a flawed masterpiece, and something that I would recommend to nearly everyone. Play the entire trilogy, start to finish, and I'll guarantee you won't regret it.

Runs well, is fun, and is a unique and unforgettable experience.

In general I would recommend this game but the only Issues I've come across while 100%ing the game were:

-Mouse issues resolved by reducing the polling rate of my mouse to 125 
-Mouse dampening not turning off even after turning it off (and setting not there in me1)
-Framerate drops when using a mouse in the first two games resolved by turning off ea in-game overlay
-In ME3 weird crashes on the citadel resolved by saving and walking around certain areas or not looking in certain direction while walking into another (Normandy's docking bay stairs behind the batarian codes terminal)

Other than that I found it quite enjoyable.

In the future, when our descendants look back to the achievements of their forerunners, they will see this game. And they shall gaze in wonder and amazement at how a masterpiece such as Mass Effect could have been made by humankind. Put simply, this game is an absolute must-play. Everything from the story to the characters; from the worldbuilding to the voice acting (and so much more) is quite frankly some of the best I have seen in any piece of media ever. Friend, this game is worth getting for the characters alone; they are that good, not to mention all the other things this game does so very well. The one and only critique I can think of is that this game requires the use of the EA Launcher, which can be a massive pain sometimes. But that pain is oh-so worth it to have but a fleeting taste of perfection. Therefore, I implore thee: deny yourself not from one of the greatest things to have graced our universe. Play Mass Effect.

Mass Effect is a life changing story franchise, and now all three of its titular games are combined into a single title; one that happens to go on sale for extremely low prices almost every other weekend. Complete with remastered graphics, easily transferable save data (important for trilogy-wide playthroughs!) and packaged with every single DLC ever produced for the franchise (minus one ME1 DLC that was lost to code hell, but it can be restored via mods). Speaking of mods, the Mass Effect franchise has one of the most solid and easily accessible modding communities on the entire internet. Almost every little nitpick anyone might have about the series can and already has been addressed by the modders. It's an absolute godsend on top of an already excellent and technologically stable title.

After completing %100 platinum, i can tell that this was such a wonderfull journey and a very nice decision to merge all games into a single edition with all downloadable content. I did spend around 110 hours to complete all games twice (except the times i played when they first released), seeing the difference between them and how they got improved by Bioware over the course of the franchises lifespan was priceless. Playing them back to back and getting lost in the deep lore and carachters of the franchise makes me think this Legendary Edition might be my favourite game. Connections between games, carachters that not died because of your choice appears in the next game and etc... Perfectly connected saga with the save import system between games so you can continue with the same carachter and consequences of what you did on the previous games. Also having all DLC content included in this package is a huge upside. Some of the DLC’s are the best additional content in gaming .(Leviathan for ME3, ShadowBroker for ME2, Omega for ME3 and many more...) 

NOTE: Due to the switch from Origin to EAplay application couple years ago, some achivements and accesibility things doesn’t synch and pop when you do them. And no fix from EA for years...

MASS EFFECT:
Mass effect is the only one in the triology that i did not play when it first came out. Time to time, I’ve heard that this is the superior game in the original triology from people around me. Unfortunately, as much as i love this game, i don’t see the legend when i play it in 2020’s. If i play this seperately today, i will definitely give it a little bit less credit but don't get me wrong, when you play all games back to back with the legendary edition, Mass Effect still shines as a must play. All in all, still a fantastic game and definitely above standarts even today with some bold downsides.

+Fantastic storyline with lots of iconic scenes, such a great way to start a franchise.
+Carachters, the lore and the events behind all races. Smart connections between all of them.
-Openworld-ish mako missions and planet exploration is garbage. Gameplay mechanics and carachter mobility kinda sucks for todays standards. 
-Role playing options are fantastic but the dialogues behind them are primitive and weaker then i expected. Needs more carachter based dialogues other than a galaxy that is danger cliche.

8/10

MASS EFFECT 2:
The GOAT. The best game in the triology for most people. And i agree. Lore and story after Mass Effect expends and drastically changes in a fantastic way with Mass Effect 2 and still avoids being a cliche soulles RPG story. A fantastic mission chain and side events, all the gameplay and dialogue negatives are cut down from the first ME, and more carachter and personality based narrative... You literally need to connect with people and talk with them to beat the game with the best ending. Shocking details with the dialogues after the first game, i think ME2 is the magnum opus of Bioware.

+Story standing more on the personal relationship side with recruiting people and doing their loyalty missions, talking with them and solving what you need with them is priceless. Still has and uses the huge events galaxywide that happened in the first game, adding more of the persona side definitely makes this game balanced and one of the best action-RPG’s ever made.
+Gameplay, gunning action and mobility definitely fits todays standards. Such a beautifull jump from ME1 to ME2

10/10

MASS EFFECT 3:
For a lot of people, this game is a dissapointment but i definitely dissagree. Ending for this wonderfull triology was not what we expected back in the day. But the quality of the missions, being the latest and the most modern version of the previous games, i think Mass Effect 3 is closer than you think to Mass Effect 2. Storyline is based on ending the huge threat to the galaxy that we were facing previous games, Mass Effect 3 figured out another way to balance between carachters, friendships and galactic history between races and the big finale to the story. Sweetspot between Mass Effect and Mass Effect 2. Had a lot of fun with it and absolutely don’t think this is a black sheep.

+Gameplay is fantastic. Everything gets more flashy with this game.
+2 of the best DLC’s (one of them adds a decent ending over the default ones we don’t like) in the franchise.
-Not quite a big jump after ME2 that it should be as the big finale. But probably because ME2 and ME3 are in the same console gen unlike the ME and the ME2 difference. 

9/10

CONCLUSION:
Almost perfectly made remastered masterpiece we have here. Great optimization and price goes down a lot in related steam events. It will be hard to get into because the first ME is a little bit technically old, but once you get lost in the story and push more into the lore, everything will make sense.
the story is sooooo amazingggg, if only the citadel DLC in Mass Effect 3 was played after the last mission, it would be a perfect trilogy

Mass Effect is hands down one of the best video-games I ever played. It captivated me from the very beginning and made me feel empty inside after it ended. There’s a lot to unpack, so to keep it simple, fun and readable, I will focus on the key pros and cons based on my experience.

Pros: 
  • The galaxy is vast and richly detailed. With various planets, alien species, and interstellar politics, you’ll feel like you’ve stepped into a sci-fi novel—except you’re living it, and there are no inconvenient paper cuts from turning pages. Really, the world-building in Mass Effect is so good, it makes the real world seem like a bad fanfic. I spent so many hours reading the index that I started to wonder if I was missing out on a future career as an intergalactic historian.

  • The game’s diverse and well-written cast provides some of the most memorable dialogues and relationships you’ll encounter in gaming. From heartfelt conversations to dramatic confrontations, the character interactions are both engaging and deeply immersive. Just be cautious, as you might realize you’re more emotionally invested in them than in your real-life relationships. Sorry, real friends, but Garrus and Miranda are just cooler. Plus, they don’t judge you for playing video games at 3 a.m.

  • Your choices matter. Like, really matter. Decisions you make can significantly impact the story and the fate of entire species. It’s like being the galaxy’s most powerful influencer, except your posts involve saving or destroying entire civilizations. No pressure though.

  • The combat system blends tactics with action. You can strategically use biotic powers, tech abilities, and firearms to take down foes. Sorry, I have no joke for this one.

  • The soundtrack and voice acting are top-tier, with a score that captures the epic feel of space exploration and voice performances that bring characters to life. I sometimes listen to the Mass Effect soundtrack when studying astronomy, and it makes the subject seem so much cooler than it really is. Seriously, it made me feel like my homework is the first step in saving the galaxy.

  • The Legendary Edition polishes up the visuals like a good Instagram filter—making everything look beautiful, especially in ME3. But let’s not get too crazy here; it’s still an older game, so don’t expect it to look like it’s fresh out of the Unreal Engine 5. It’s more like, “Hey, look, I’m a vintage beauty with a facelift.” Not bad, right?

  • The cost of this game during sales is super cheap considering the amount of top-tier content it provides. Seriously, this game offers so much that it almost feels like stealing.

  • There are bunch of good mods available that can enhance your experience even further. Whether you’re looking to tweak the visuals, adjust gameplay mechanics, or just add some more content, the modding community has you covered.

Cons: 
  • The planet exploration in the first game is as exciting as watching paint dry on an alien wall. It’s mostly just empty areas with different textures, like someone gave you a sandbox and forgot to add the sand. But hey, at least the sequels figured it out and ditched that mechanic.

  • The first game of the series can feel a bit dated. Some gameplay mechanics and user interface elements might remind you of a bygone era of gaming. Think of it as classic sci-fi nostalgia with a sprinkle of clunky charm.

  • Some of the side tasks can get repetitive and overly time-consuming if you aim for 100% completion. You might start questioning your life choices as you scan yet another barren planet for resources


To sum it up, Mass Effect is an outstanding RPG shooter, particularly if you love good storytelling, memorable characters, and a richly imagined universe. Just be prepared for some serious post-game withdrawal—it’s the kind of game that will have you staring at the credits, wondering what to do with your life now that the adventure is over. It will make you question if your life will ever be as exciting again. Spoiler alert: probably not. But hey, at least you’ll always have the memories!

Finished the Trilogy at the first time. I tried to play in ME1 several times in my life but always was distracted by boring gameplay. 
I have no reference with old versions and had no expectations based on that.

What can I say, I really enjoyed by the story trip. I heared that the final ending confused fans a lot when the game was released, but in my case it's ended like I expected. Fair enough and satisfying end of the Trilogy.

Best Side Quests: Mass Effect 2
Best Ending: Mass Effect 3
Best Music: Mass Effect 3
Best Romances: Mass Effect 2
Best Game in the Trilogy: Mass Effect 2

Minuses:

Gameplay. I understand that the first game was released in 2008, but game by game it's not Improved so much. As result in the 3rd chapter I was burned out because I had 3 actions that was assinged on 1 button. When you press run the character jumps or hides, etc. You can get used to it, but in some tight battles it's annoying to much

Boring game elements. For example in the Mass Effect 2 it was resources gringing, in Mass Effect it's frequent jumps to the Citadel just to have a short conversation with NPC. 

Pluses:

The Main Plot. Apart of all minuses the story is catchy and it grows more once you decided to explore all side quests. Especially I was touched by Mass Effect 2, when each small side quest deserves your time. 

Variativity. I really enjoyed how I could play "bad boy" in Mass Effect 2! You could say and do whatewer you want and you cound't predict concequences of your choices. And it was organic and funny. Unfortunatelly, devs cuted that in ME3 and there was less fun to play bad part

Characters. Most of them are so remembered and after 100+ hours in the Trilogy you feel their different personalities and characters. Unfortunatelly in ME3 devs decided to switch interractions with companions to the Sims mode with appartments meetings. 

Finally I would say Mass Effect deserves to be played for each player who likes single deep plot. Just give it a chance and you will see how you will fall into the beauty of the endless space full of life and advantures.

Absolutely a great way to experience the original trilogy. The updated visuals and UI for Mass Effect 1 are great, and the collection includes (almost) every piece of content for all 3 games.

In spite of the weird, questionable design choices they did to the visuals in their attempt to give the games a facelift, this is more or less a definitive version of the original trilogy.

The first game is missing the Pinnacle Station DLC (though not Bioware's fault on this) if you care that much, but using the Mako is SLIGHTLY more bearable thanks to the added speed boosters. The Mako is still pretty aggravating. It's some of Bioware's finest work in terms of writing and worldbuilding, so it is very much worth it if you take your time playing it.

Mass Effect 2 is my personal favourite, as that is where the gameplay actually becomes decent (despite the lack of tech and biotic powers). The story may be simple, but the character writing is top notch, and it makes you invested in the fate of each character. It's also the first game where you get to romance Tali the best girl (don't fight me on this, it's not up for debate).

Mass Effect 3 takes the combat of the second, and refines it to such a polish that the combat alone is worth playing, especially since weapon modding makes its return from the first game. Aside from the opportunity to ascend Garrus into godhood with the correct build and weapons, the writing overall is pretty weak. It also has the worst DLC of the three games, so temper your expectations when you play through them.

If you want to relive the good and the bad of the trilogy, or if you want to experience it for the first time, this is the best way to do it... Outside of already having the original trilogy and DLC on the XBOX 360 before the 360's Online Marketplace shut down.

I am new to the Mass Effect series, and am glad I came across it. The trilogy has jumped to the top of my favorite games of all time. I started playing the first game and played all the way to the end of 3. The story is very well written, and the voice acting is fantastic. Jennifer Hales stands out for her performance as female Shepard. Mark Meer does a good job with male Shepard but is not as compelling as Hale's performance. The first game was the best of the series overall but all three were very solid. The companion characters are the best in 1 and 2 and most characters reappear in 3. 3 is by far the weakest game but is still very good. I find that as part of a 3 act series that the ending to game 3 works fine as it is. I know a lot of players disliked the ending to 3, but if you look at the games as part 1 - the beginning, part 2 - the middle, and part 3 as the end of Shepard's journey then the ending is a fitting end. The series also gets major kudos from me for including a strong disabled character. Joker is an excellent pilot and very skilled. The other characters don't pity him or make a big deal about it. They simple treat him as a part of the crew and a good soldier. He has several great scenes in the series and it doesn't get much better than when he has to fight off invaders by himself.

Mass Effect is Dragon Age for sci-fi fans (not surprising, considering the franchises share a dev). It embodies the same caliber of detailed story and missions, a nice variety in characters with their own personalities, plenty of skills to develop, etc. I feel the interface is done well to promote the sci-fi feel of the games. The major difference that I can draw between the games is the combat system; DA focuses on hand-to-hand combat with detailed tactics and a battle pause feature while ME is primarily a shooter with augmented abilities, and more simplified tactics (you can place your squadmates in certain locations and designate targets). Probably the most interesting thing is how different yet equally functional each game in the trilogy is, just like Dragon Age. It requires some adjustment as you progress, but it prevents you from experiencing "rinse and repeat" when it comes to game sequels. I partly hope the rumors of a ME4 installment continuing Shepard's story are true - although, who could you possibly be facing now? - and I wouldn't be surprised considering the impending release of DA4 this year after a decade hiatus. All in all, you shouldn't pass this up, especially if it's on sale.

After hitting their lowest point with the consecutive releases of the abysmal spin-off Mass Effect: Andromeda (2017), which led to putting the series on ice, and the soulless live-service cash grab attempt titled Anthem (2019), the developers at BioWare turned their focus to the next entry in the Dragon Age series. However, the development has faced many challenges, repeatedly pushing the potential release date further into the future. In late 2020, BioWare announced a remastered version of the original Mass Effect trilogy (2007-2012) titled Mass Effect Legendary Edition (2021), and shortly after revealed that the Mass Effect series would continue. Since the next Dragon Age is still in the final stages of development, the next Mass Effect is still undoubtedly many years away. In the meantime, the release of MELE has served as a successful intermission for fans between the main line entries. But the question remains: should you play it? 

At its core, the Mass Effect series is a third-person cover-shooter with light RPG elements, set in a near-future sci-fi version of the Milky Way galaxy. From the ruins of a long-lost civilization found on Mars, humanity uncovers the technology to travel across the galaxy. Humans soon discover they are not alone and eventually ally with the Galactic Council, which consists of several alien races. There is no magic in space; instead, it’s called biotics-the power to harness dark energy and move matter at your will. With that in mind, there are three main ways to deal damage in fights: combat, technology, and biotic skills. The player chooses a class for their character based on one of these three approaches or a combination of two. For example, the Engineer class focuses solely on tech skills, while Vanguard wreaks havoc up close with a blend of combat and biotic abilities. Before and after a battle, there is usually a lot of dialogue, where the player can play the hero with Paragon choices, or be the “cool guys don’t look at explosions” with Renegade dialogue options, all provided by the patented dialogue wheel.

Arguably, the first game, Mass Effect, is the weakest in the series. The player takes control of Commander Shepard, an Alliance Marine who becomes the first human Spectre Agent for the Galactic Council, tasked with taking down the rogue Spectre, Saren. On this journey, Shepard is accompanied by a diverse squad of different races, all of whom have a bone to pick with Saren. People on the internet often remind us that the combat is outdated in this game. They are correct. What they fail to realize is that it's the most enjoyable part of the game. The combat remains consistent from start to finish. Pick the Soldier class, equip heavy armor and a shotgun, and the player rarely needs to worry about the cover system, allowing them to focus on running and gunning foes at close range. The story is not as stable. It starts slow but eventually builds up. There are only four main missions between the prologue and epilogue, and the plot only becomes interesting near the end during the fourth mission. The squadmates Shepard gathers are the main reason players don’t quit after the initial hours, but the dialogue is often insufferable. Shepard talks to everyone like how people used to talk to the early smartphone voice assistants: “Tell me about the history of your race”, and NPCs respond as if reading straight from Wikipedia. But the most annoying part of ME is the Uncharted Worlds side missions. The player lands on a small region of a planet with a physics-defying vehicle, the Mako, and must traverse the tallest mountains and steepest valleys to reach their destination, which is an identical warehouse or bunker on every planet. These missions are optional, but they build the world and provide experience points and loot necessary to tackle the sudden difficulty spikes in the main missions. 

The second game, Mass Effect 2, is a significant improvement over its predecessor. The Uncharted Worlds missions are gone and the concept of a few longer main story missions is replaced with many shorter, linear episodes. The dialogue is vastly improved, as Shepard and various NPCs now converse more like real people. The combat is also more streamlined now. The player no longer constantly finds new gear throughout the game but instead acquires a few weapons to stick with. This removes the inventory management almost completely. The lack of armor tiers and the fact that the enemies always hit Shepard if staying in the open, forces the player to stick to cover. The skill tree focuses solely on battle abilities, and the final upgrade of each power offers a choice between two different options. The story picks up from where ME ended, throwing the player straight into the action. This time, the plot unfolds like a heist movie: half of the game is spent on Shepard gathering the best talent across the galaxy for a high-stakes mission, and the other half is spent on Shepard getting to know the hired individuals and gaining their loyalty. When it’s not guaranteed that everyone will return alive from the mission, the team members wish to make amends so they can die in peace if it comes to that. It’s in Shepard’s best interest to be there for their squad. This is the highlight of the trilogy. However, ME2 is not perfect. There is a tedious scanning minigame that the player must do. They scan planets and that way gather minerals. The minerals are used to upgrade the stats of squadmates, equipment, and the ship. The Legendary Edition includes all the DLCs, but only the two new squadmates, Lair of the Shadow Broker, and Arrival are worth the time. The latter two are best completed near the end of the game. 

After ME2, the final game in the series, Mass Effect 3, starts with a bang. The entire galaxy is under serious threat, and it is up to Shepard and their crew to save the galaxy. Facing nearly impossible odds, Shepard must build alliances across the different races, no matter the cost. Gameplay-wise, the combat builds on the foundation of ME2, but this time it’s polished to a new level. Shepard feels more agile, the cover system is smoother, and there’s a much larger variety of enemies to face on the battlefield. Different weapon types are no longer locked behind the class choices, like in ME2. Instead, there is a weight system in place: the more weapons Shepard carries, the longer the skill cooldowns are. The good things end there. Unfortunately, ME3 was rushed (likely by EA), and it doesn’t live up to the expectations set by its predecessor. For example, there are fewer squadmates in ME3 compared to the amazing cast in ME2. And the worst offense: the original ending was a disaster. Although they tried to do damage control by releasing a few patches and the Leviathan DLC, they couldn’t fix the fundamental problems related to poor writing. The ending is just less bad now. All the DLCs in ME3 are worthwhile additions, but make sure to play the Leviathan and Citadel DLCs near the end, preferably just before the final mission. 

Even though the ending leaves a bad taste, the journey is amazing. If the player is patient enough to endure most of ME, they’ll get to fully enjoy ME2, and the ball is dropped only near the end of ME3. It’s a shame that the development team was in such a hurry that they couldn’t deliver a competent conclusion to the saga. The gameplay itself doesn’t win any awards, but it improves with each installment. The game is rich in lore and story, and though the plot starts slow, once it grabs the player, it doesn’t let go until near the end. But the main selling point of the series is the squadmates Shepard meets along the way. It’s no surprise that, to this day, people still comment online about how Garrus Vakarian is their favorite side character in any game. If sci-fi interests you and you are not afraid of playing a seventh-generation cover-shooter, Mass Effect Legendary Edition is worth considering.

Mass Effect Legendary Edition: A Solid Remaster with Room for Improvement

The Mass Effect Legendary Edition is a commendable effort to revitalize a beloved trilogy. The visual upgrades are noticeable, and the performance improvements are welcome. The inclusion of all DLC is a fantastic bonus, offering additional depth to the already rich narrative.
That being said, the trilogy's age does show in certain areas. Combat, especially in the first game, can feel clunky at times. While the Mako has been improved, it still remains a divisive element. Moreover, some of the original game's pacing issues persist.
Mass Effect 2 remains the standout, with its gripping story, memorable characters, and refined gameplay. Mass Effect 3, while improved, still suffers from pacing issues in certain parts, and its ending, though addressed through DLC, continues to be a point of contention for many.
Ultimately, the Legendary Edition is a solid package that offers a great experience for newcomers and a nostalgic trip for veterans. It's a step in the right direction, but it doesn't entirely mask the original games' inherent flaws.
While the remastered trilogy is undoubtedly enjoyable, it's essential to approach it with tempered expectations, understanding that it's a classic series with its strengths and weaknesses.

[h1] Schqrk’s Review: Mass Effect Legendary Edition - The Epic Sci-Fi Saga Reimagined [/h1]

[h2] Review Date: [/h2]
August 14, 2024

[h2] Overall Rating: [/h2]
9/10 ⭐

[h2] Completion: [/h2]
100%

[hr][/hr]

[h2] Introduction [/h2]

[i]Mass Effect Legendary Edition[/i], developed by BioWare, revitalizes the acclaimed Mass Effect trilogy with enhanced graphics, improved gameplay, and all previously released DLCs. This remastered collection offers both newcomers and long-time fans a chance to experience Commander Shepard’s intergalactic journey with modern polish and refinements.

[h2] Graphics and Visuals [/h2]

[✔️] 🌌 Stunning Remaster: The Legendary Edition features significant visual upgrades, including higher resolution textures, improved lighting, and more detailed character models. The remaster brings the rich and expansive universe of Mass Effect to life with striking clarity and detail.

[✔️] 🌠 Enhanced Environments: Each of the three games in the trilogy benefits from enhanced environmental graphics, making planets, space stations, and alien worlds more immersive and visually engaging than ever before.

[h2] Gameplay and Mechanics [/h2]

[✔️] 🔫 Improved Combat: The remaster includes refinements to combat mechanics, making gameplay smoother and more responsive. The improvements extend across the trilogy, ensuring a more polished experience from Mass Effect 1 to Mass Effect 3.

[✔️] 🎮 Unified Experience: The Legendary Edition integrates the best elements from the original games, including updated controls and quality-of-life improvements. Players can enjoy a seamless transition through the trilogy with modernized gameplay mechanics.

[h2] Story and Narrative [/h2]

[✔️] 📜 Epic Saga: The trilogy’s narrative remains intact, delivering an epic story of Commander Shepard’s quest to save the galaxy from the Reapers. The remaster preserves the impactful choices and branching storylines that define the Mass Effect series.

[✔️] 🌟 Character Development: The characters and their relationships are as compelling as ever. The remaster retains the rich character interactions and emotional depth, allowing players to fully engage with the story and its protagonists.

[h2] Audio and Sound Design [/h2]

[✔️] 🎵 Immersive Soundtrack: The iconic soundtrack of the Mass Effect series is preserved, enhancing the epic and atmospheric feel of the game. The music complements the story’s highs and lows, adding to the immersive experience.

[✔️] 🔊 Enhanced Sound Effects: The remaster improves sound effects, making combat and environmental sounds more realistic and impactful. This enhancement contributes to the overall immersion and enjoyment of the game.

[h2] Content and Replayability [/h2]

[✔️] 📚 Complete Collection: The Legendary Edition includes all DLCs from the original trilogy, offering additional content and storylines that enrich the overall experience. The inclusion of all expansions ensures a comprehensive playthrough.

[✔️] 🔄 Replay Value: The trilogy’s branching narratives and numerous choices provide substantial replay value. Players can explore different character interactions and story outcomes, making each playthrough unique.

[h2] Pros and Highlights [/h2]

[✔️] 🌟 High-Quality Remaster: The visual and gameplay improvements make Mass Effect Legendary Edition a definitive version of the trilogy, providing an enhanced experience that respects the original games.

[✔️] 🚀 Comprehensive Package: The inclusion of all DLCs and quality-of-life updates creates a complete and refined experience for both new players and veterans of the series.

[h2] Cons and Drawbacks [/h2]

[❌] ⏳ Minor Bugs: While the remaster is generally well-polished, some players may encounter minor bugs or issues that were present in the original games. These do not significantly detract from the overall experience but are worth noting.

[❌] 🎨 Limited Changes: Some players might find that certain aspects of the original games remain unchanged, such as specific gameplay mechanics or story elements. While the remaster enhances many areas, it does not fundamentally alter the core experience.

[h2] Additional Comments [/h2]

[i]Mass Effect Legendary Edition[/i] successfully revitalizes the beloved trilogy with enhanced graphics, improved gameplay, and comprehensive content. It offers an excellent opportunity for both newcomers and returning players to experience Commander Shepard’s saga in its best form.

[h2] Why 9/10? [/h2]

⭐ [i]Mass Effect Legendary Edition[/i] earns a 9/10 for its high-quality remaster, comprehensive content, and successful integration of the trilogy’s classic elements with modern enhancements. The minor issues do not overshadow the significant improvements and the enduring appeal of the series.

I really enjoyed the story and seeing the results of your choices. Especially seeing your choices carry over to the next game. Some of the gameplay mechanics however felt like a step backwards with each game. One example is each weapon in Mass Effect can fire so many times before overheating. Mass Effect 2 now you need coolant clips and heavy weapons ammo. Mass Effect 3 now you need ammo that's specific to each weapon.
Another example of the gameplay mechanics taking steps backwards is Mass Effect you can carry one weapon of each type. Mass Efect 2 you can carry one of each weapon you can use. Now Mass Effect 3 you have carrying weight.
The skill system in Mass Effect was also complex, the skill system in Mass Effect 2 was very simplified and the skill system in Mass Effect 3 wasn't as complex as Mass Effect but was more complex than Mass Effect 2.
Things like that kind of make them not feel like they're all in the same series. Still I would say it's worth playing them for the storyline and choices you can make.

Mass Effect 1:
ME1 is a great game overall but some of the side content is a bit lacking as the areas can get pretty repetitive with a lot more backtracking than I would normally be okay with. It was really cool to see how Bioware built upon KOTOR as this feels like a slicker version of it aside from the combat. Some of the areas (especially planetary exploration) could've been streamlined quite a bit and a lot of sections were just tedious to traverse in general but I admired the ambition.

Mass Effect 2:
ME2 Improves upon ME1 in almost every way, although I felt that some of it was a little too simplified in terms of combat and game play but most changes were welcome. ME2 introduced some of the best characters (mostly Mordin) I've seen in a game and built upon a roster that seemed bare-bones in comparison. The resource gathering was pretty tedious and mind-numbing though.

Mass Effect 3:
ME3 is quite dark in comparison to the former games but also has some of the best moments of levity in the series. This entry felt like it was combining the best elements of the previous games in the minute-to-minute game play while continuing to build upon the formula. The combat is pretty easy though as it's not hard to find a something that works really well which trivializes the whole game. Some of the moments you share with your companions were some of the best/funniest/most heart-warming scenes I'd seen in a game and it was really nice to be able to spend more time with them all (especially my boyfriend Garrus) in the Citadel DLC areas. Also f*** you for killing my favourite characters.

This is one of the best trilogies/series I've ever played. I'm not a huge fan of the paragon/renegade system as it sort of makes you want to restrict your dialogue to one obvious option once you've decided who you want your character to be but I can overlook it given how fun some of the dialogue can be and that not all options are as black and white as they seem (don't be afraid to mix it up now and then, it won't ruin your character). It was not only great to see how all the characters and the world evolved but the games themselves. I went through just about every emotion you could go through with my time playing and I won't forget it any time soon. Play this before you die.

Great story, non linear and choices do matter. it is worth overcoming what is now a dated UI and clunky at times gameplay. i'm told ME2 is the best of the three, and plays better, but one should play the 1st game prior to that. and i do, and the story is worth the dated gameplay. overall, great story and good game.

Including all three original Mass Effect games helps keep this one pretty cheap for the entertainment value. Get it on sale of course, it's not like creatives are getting much of a cut when you buy an EA product and they made sure to include the horrible EA launcher.

The update is not that impressive graphically, but the game is pretty easy on the system and fans so that's fine IMO. The second layer of launcher is annoying, I don't see why it needed to be full-screen and have its own credit video to just be 3 buttons opening the respective games.

There are some nice quality of life features; the Mako has a "sprint" type boost now. ME1's movement and gunplay have been adjusted some to bring them in line with later stuff; still no thermal clips (thankfully), but the running and aiming feel different (on the bright side, headshots are buffed to be in line with later entries in the series).

The "uninhabited world" map design from Mass Effect 1 remains some of the genuinely worst map designs I have ever seen in any game. Even at the time, I can't believe making players drive your weirdly-balanced tank up mountain sides to get to things was considered good design.

Wow, just wow.

I first encountered this game when a friend of mine rented/bought it, back when it released on X360. I watched him play through a lot of it, but never gave it a go. Years later, generally knowing the story arc of the 1st, I bought ME2 when it released, and played maybe half of it before I put it down and lent it to someone else.

Later on, the 3rd game came out and a lot of people were complaining about the ending. For even longer, I abstained from playing this trilogy.

Finally, 2024, I find the collection on the super cheap (I don't even remember how much it was; it was less than 10 bucks) and power through it all in about 3 weeks.

What an excellent and effective story. I was moved by the world and actually felt more and more excitement and tension as every point of the story moved forward. There are many payoffs in the final game that culminated from actions from the first game. I felt all of the stakes as if I was part of that world.

If it's cheap, it's worth playing through the whole thing, and see what your Shepard will do. It has a very cinematic feel to it, yet still is a game. I think most of my enjoyment came from all of the relationships you form with comrades and people across the galaxy. The game has a way of making me feel like those moments as a child, and I brought all of my action figures together for the "final stand". ME 2 and then ME 3 both find ways of replicating that feeling, but in slightly different ways.

Check it out. There is a reason it is so beloved. I am glad I finally gave it a try.

PS. Yeah the EA app having to run is actually a huge pain. I found one of the smoothest ways to prevent issues with booting the game, is to just start the EA app first and let it load in before you do anything with the Steam launcher.

There's a ton of good, and unfortunately a lot of roughness that still exists in the Legendary edition.

ME1: I played this on release way back. Fantastic universe building, characters, music, aesthetics. Mediocre combat and some tedious mechanics. Runs like garbage on modern PCs unfortunately. Thankfully it's only several hours to get through if you've never played before which I recommend you do. Side missions don't add much so you can skip. The magic of this first game is a rare gem.

ME2: Swaps the hard sci-fi of the first game for modern Star Wars. New characters are just bad versions of the cast from ME1 who get sidelined. New combat system is not very good and makes no sense in universe. Tedious mechanics from ME1 are now frustrating and still waste time. DLC is garbage, especially the characters. I played through once on release and that was enough. Sadly a lot of small choices here can affect ME3. I'd just use an editor to get the flags you want.

ME3: They finally figured out what works and what doesn't for the most part. The lousy new characters of ME2 get sidelined this time, but still are written better than before. The main cast comes back, some more than others. All very strong except for the Prothean who came with a DLC and he sucks- just doesn't fit visually or narratively. He doesn't really add much either. Much longer than the previous games, but you never feel like you're doing the same thing over and over. Decisions actually matter and play a strong part in the story. Narrative is strong except for the few moments of Kai Leng who just ruins every scene he's in as the primary antagonist (so bad a mod exists to patch him out). Combat ranges from okay to pretty good. Tedious mechanics are all gone. The ending is alright. DLC is great and adds a lot for existing characters. Lots of replayability, but unfortunately a lot of flags need to be triggered from ME2.

Overall it's all over the place, but the universe and end result of ME3 is worth the experience.

The decisions running through the series were epic and the writing was very good throughout. 
Was interesting playing them back to back and seeing how much the gameplay improved across the series, by the third the combat felt pretty good and it gets better again in Andromeda.

I'm a HUGE Mass Effect fanboy and own all the ME titles on various platforms, including the original boxed DVDs for ME1 and ME2. I do a playthrough at least once a year, just like with Fallout 3 and 4, because the storylines are so immersive and replayable. When the Legendary Edition was released on Steam in mid-May 2021, I had already prepaid months in advance, excited about the remastered versions of all three titles. While I enjoy ME Andromeda as well, the original trilogy will never get old. The storyline, the characters, the gameplay—they're all timeless!

I recently started a new playthrough and just finished ME1. Even 17 years after its initial release, the experience is incredibly crisp, thanks to the 4K remaster. If you don’t have this in your game library yet, be sure to pick it up during this month’s special promotion!

One downside, however, is that despite being distributed on Steam, you still need the new EA app to launch the game. It's often buggy, with achievements sometimes failing to unlock or sync. While this isn't a major issue for me since I'm focused on the experience, it's something potential buyers should be aware of.

As someone who typically hates story games, I can say without a doubt this is one of the most engaging and enjoyable game I have every played. While I usually skip cutscenes in story games, focusing more on the gameplay, I have found myself going out of my way to talk to everyone I can and complete many side quests. This game pulls you in by allowing you to make a personal connection which each of your crewmates that makes it feel as if you are actually a part of the game. The dialogue choices also make your character feel real compared to other games that force you to just sit there while the characters talk and you as a player have no say in the conversations. I haven't even finished the first game in this trilogy, but I am still having a blast. I would highly recommend getting this game as it is 3 games in one and is on sale right now for $9.

TLDR: This is an amazing game that it is only $9 for three games that all progressively get better and carry over story choices you made in the previous game.

I'm midway through my second playthough (the second one being modded but the first being vanilla) and all I have to say is... GET THE GAME! IT IS SO WORTH IT! It is my favorite series, as soon as I finished my first playthough I went through gamer sadness where all I could think of was Mass Effect. Allow me to explain the pros and the cons to the trilogy:

PROS:
-You get all three games for the price of one. It is absolutely worth your money.
-All of the DLC is free and included in legendary edition. Granted, there are a few DLC I wish I didn't have to play (I'm looking at you, Arrival) but there are some of the best DLC I've played in any game in the Legendary Edition (Citadel DLC my beloved).
-The story writing of this game is A+ tier. I would put S tier, but there are some things I'm going to talk about in the cons that I just can't forgive.
-The characters are so well written, even some of the background characters have so much character and interest. You will genuinely feel bad for decisions in this game.
-Character customization was ahead of it's time. At 2007, I wasn't expecting much character customization (or any at all) but I was very pleasantly surprised!
-Romances are well earned. It takes time to build a romance, to actually get to know the character and be there for him. Granted, some romances are better (sorry Kaidan, I have to stick with my man Garrus) but there are many to choose from.
-Throughout the three games, you are deeply invested in the character you make. Paragon or Renegade, even a mix of both, you are actively making decisions that will effect the entire playthrough. Things that happened in ME1 will be important even at the end of ME3. That creates a deep connection to the character you make and how they interact with others.

CONS:
-You have to go through the EA launcher. I know, it was expected, but the EA launcher frustrates me greatly. It's not the fault of the game whatsoever to have to go through EA, so this isn't so much a con to the game as it is that you have to go through two launchers that have to agree with each other all the time. When it comes to modding, this can be a serious pain.
-No mod support. This has caused me so many headaches... I spent three days just trying to troubleshoot the mods and get everything to work. Now it works, but it takes about thirty minutes to launch. Due in part to the fact that the cloud storage gets very full very fast. And there is no way to clear that cloud storage (trust me, I've tried).
-Some of the DLC is awful, and a couple of them you must play. Arrival is by far the most irritating DLC I've ever played. And it's required to set the tone for the beginning of ME3.
-Being a completionist will hurt you. Trying to finish every mission, get every gun, get every achievement, is going to cost a lot of time and patience. Especially in ME1 & ME2. In ME1 you have the Mako, a tank that can withstand a lot of damage, but is really slow and can't go over terrain really well unless you're gifted at driving Warthogs in Halo (and I still struggled). The Hammerhead is even worse, it's thin as a tissue which makes you blow up and have to restart whatever mission you had, as well as making horrible noises that make you wish you could rip out your ears. Mako missions are more often in ME1 (practically 70% of the game) and luckily Hammerhead missions are sparse (about 5% of the game).
SPOILERS:
-The story will kick you while you're down. There are some amazing story beats like the Genophage arc with Mordin and Wrex, and the Rannoch arc with Legion and Tali. The Genophage arc being genuinely one of my favorite and most satisfying arcs (when done correctly). However, some arcs will disappoint you.
-The literal ending of the game. To save you heartache now, if you want to play vanilla: look up a guide to "the perfect ending" or if you don't mind a few mods: look up "the happy ending mod" and "play citadel dlc after the end" on Nexus. I won't get too much into it because it enraged me so much, but the ending is deeply unsatisfying.
-Your character is with you all three games... and will die. And be revived for sure once, as we see in ME2, but the ending leaves little hope if you don't get the perfect ending. It is the cause for my deep dissatisfaction with the ending of the game. And you don't even get an epilogue. There is no choice of self sacrifice or not, Shepard doesn't get to retire and have a family, there is simply no genuine closure with a trilogy that was meant to stay a trilogy. I blame EA primarily for creating an unnecessary time crunch onto Bioware, causing this mess of an ending.
-Some characters and romances are really bad. Specifically, Jacob. I will not forgive you, Jacob. I highly recommend to any femshep that wants to play this game, do not romance him. There are many other great options. Jacob will straight up cheat on your character, as well as throw himself into danger multiple times. I recommend not listening to him at all.
-Legion deserved better. If you're okay with modding, I highly encourage getting the "Early Recruitment" mod for Legion. Legion is genuinely one of the most interesting characters that you don't get to learn a lot about due to the fact that they're locked behind a "this is the end of the game" timer. They're also REQUIRED to retrieve (not sell, don't listen to Miranda about selling them) AND commit to the loyalty mission in order to properly complete the Rannoch arc.

I could go on and on about what's amazing about the game, what the game could fix, but what matters is you getting the game and PLAYING IT! It is a unique experience for everyone playing the game themselves. Don't let my big block of CONS turn you away from this amazing series, as most of it was just nitpicky. Do take the mods into consideration however if you want the best experience playing Mass Effect.
For now, I'm going to go continue my second playthrough. Please get the game and comment how much you enjoyed it!

Mass Effect 1 is an unpolished gem. The attention to exposition and world-crafting is impeccable. The remaster reworks some gameplay elements but can't resolve the core issues- this is a poorly balanced RPG/Shooter with very lacklustre AI.

Mass Effect 2 is better polished. It offers compelling set piece missions and narratives but ends up being more on rails than ME1 and the overall narrative direction takes some questionable turns. Gameplay much improved though and is an excellent experience in its own right.

Mass Effect 3 exacerbates the issues in ME2. Narrative direction is out the window, though many of the individual pieces are well crafted. Introduces some truly cringy side characters.

Overall the whole experience is marred with hard crash bugs that have no business being in a remastered game, and that significantly detracts from the experience. This is compounded by being forced to use an EA launcher that straight up refused to run initially and has been offering repeated inexplicable errors since. Mass Effect has ambitions of being a story experience, but the narrative flow that it tries to weave is broken and frustrated by the aforementioned bugs, poor level design (ME1) and cringe (ME3). I wouldn't necessarily say you *shouldn't* play this game, because it has a lot to offer to space opera RPG fans, just that if you do, you should expect to be let down repeatedly.

Combat: NPCs have their own classes and skills. Their movements are clumsy even with your commands.

I have played the Mass Effect series 5 or so times in my life. This was one of my favorite game series to play while growing up. Being able to play the entire series again has been insanely fun and a great use of time in my life. Excusing a couple of DLCs here and there that I wasn't able to play when I was younger, I remember this game like the back of my hand and it has been a treat to revisit.

All of this to be said; I had never played all of the DLC's in the third game and I didn't know what I was missing.

The Citadel DLC in Mass Effect 3 has easily become my favorite part of this series by far. I wish I had played it sooner. The insane switch to a more comedic, lighthearted experience in the Mass Effect universe was jarring at first, but I quickly came around to enjoy it so much. It genuinely made me laugh at times, and being able to play with characters that you haven't seen much in this game was really nostalgic in a way. The scene where you fight with everyone was really cool to experience as well. 

But I think my favorite part about this DLC had to be the Party. Being able to mingle with everyone, see how characters that never met interact with each other. My heart felt so full and happy the morning after. After I had talked to everyone with their hangovers, I felt a sense of peace and calm. Something you rarely get in this series. It felt like waking up at a sleepover with your friends, and it was a feeling that genuinely made me say to myself "Damn, I wish I didn't have to leave this moment."

The next time I play this series again, it will be for that moment.

Mass Effect Legendary Edition is truly one of the best multi-game narrative experiences of all time. This remastered collection brings together the iconic Mass Effect trilogy, enhancing the visuals and gameplay while preserving the epic story that fans have loved for years. The game's narrative depth, complex characters, and rich universe make it a masterpiece of storytelling in gaming.

The journey through the Mass Effect universe, as Commander Shepard, is an emotional and thrilling experience. The series offers an unparalleled sense of choice and consequence, where decisions impact the storyline and character relationships across all three games. The remastered edition provides updated graphics and improved mechanics, making it more accessible and visually stunning, without losing the essence of the original games.

Every few years, I find myself drawn back to replay this epic saga. The combination of sci-fi adventure, intricate character development, and moral dilemmas keeps the experience fresh and engaging. Whether you're exploring the Citadel, uncovering the mysteries of the Reapers, or forging alliances with diverse alien species, the Mass Effect universe is rich with lore and excitement.

The Legendary Edition is not just a nostalgia trip for longtime fans but also an excellent entry point for new players. It successfully modernizes the trilogy while maintaining the integrity of the original narrative and gameplay. This collection is a must-play for anyone who appreciates deep storytelling and immersive RPGs.

In conclusion, Mass Effect Legendary Edition is a timeless collection that continues to set the standard for narrative-driven games. It’s a series that deserves to be experienced over and over again, and I can't recommend it highly enough. Whether you're a returning fan or new to the series, this is an epic journey worth taking.

Mass Effect, needs no introduction... 
Is what many would say when asked to speak of it. 
It is a giant in the RPG genre, and I know many who consider it to be their favorite franchise. 
I do not know many games, where different choices pass onto and influence the following game and ITS choices in meaningful ways. 
It's not something that happens really.
What developer would have the courage, and gall to create a game, knowing the fulfillment of choices made, might never come to fruition if the franchise fails. Such a tailored experience is almost doomed to fall through on paper. 
Bioware did it though. 
And what a massive achievement that was, and still is. 
That being said Mass Effect was never perfect, EA certainly didn't make it better on that part. 
Whether you prefer the original RPG system in 1 or the compact more fast-paced ARPG system in 2 and 3 there is enjoyment to be had. In the end we were/are all here for the story, the characters and the universe.

Having just finished this trilogy for the second time, I figured now would be as good a time as any to leave a review.

It's a beautiful story that keeps raising the stakes in each new game.  Your choices matter.  Whether that be a small conversation with a friend early in the first game or deciding the fate of multiple entire races in the third game.  The relationships you build with squad members almost all feel true to life.  You feel genuinely bad when you upset a squad member, it feels guilty to hold their lives in yours hands, and you feel pangs of  sadness when crew members you've sent hundreds of hours with beg for more time with you near the end of the third game.

The entire galaxy feels fleshed out and alive.  The history of settlements, planets, clusters, individuals, and races are all interesting.  It feels "lived in" in the same way Blade Runner and the original Star Wars movies do.  

Expect lots of okay combat (in the first game) and really good combat (in the second and third games.)  Some exploration in the first game, a slightly stripped back mission structure in the second game, and the perfection of that hub-based mission structure in the third game.  

I don't really know what else to say.  I miss my friends I've spent the last ~250 hours with (across two playthroughs.) I miss Tali as she evolved from a kid on her Pilgrimage to a team leader to an Admiral and a lover.  I miss Garrus as he evolved from a cop who played loose with the rules to a mercenary to a leader of the Turians.  Liara was always there as my closest ally.  Anderson as a father figure.  Wrex as an absolute homie.  Even Ashley as she gradually got over her reasonable distrust of aliens and grew up.

It's easy to Google "Games like Mass Effect" to try and find something that will legitimately make you FEEL something the way these games do, but Mass Effect really is one of a kind.

Mass Effect 1:
The story is so simple because it was a build up for their next game, they explained the Reapers(the main enemies in the game) really well. The strongest feature in this game that even the other two games lack is the RPG mechanic. leveling up in ME1 feels so rewarding and don't forget how the equipment works, i prefer how equipment works in ME1 because it feels familiar to RPG compared to their next games which is basically gave you a stat boost, the only bad thing about this feature is lack of design and you can wear a set of the armor and cannot change every part of it. 
Overall i gave it a 9.3/10


Mass Effect 2:
The combat is much better in ME2, even better than ME1 Legendary. Sadly, it lacks of RPGs mechanic and they changed how the armor works. The good thing about the armor system in this game is you can modify a specific part of it(but not all of them). Don't expect all the QoL feature from ME1 Legendary got back into this game, but you will get used to it.  the best part of this game is the side quest and the story, i think they handle the loyalty mission really well because you can learn their backstory and solving their problem, and i love the main story in this game the pacing can be a little too slow because how long the map is but it is not as slow as ME1 imo. and don't forget how memorable the final mission without spoiling you, the game gave you a burden how hard to leading your team, one mistakes your team can get killed easily. 
Overall i gave ME2 a 10/10


Mass Effect 3:
Most of my issue with ME2 was fixed in ME3 gameplay wise, the combat feels fast pace, your companion AI more useful, and much more. They also add more teammate interaction, it's minor changes but significant because your teammate feels more alive and not just standing there. i also love the main story although it felt shorter if you only count the main story alone. But the reason why i beat ME3 so long is because the DLCs, they are longer than ME2 and better imo. My favorite one was Citadel DLC because how much laugh and happiness i had, plus they also add the side activity in this DLC. Honestly the ending is not that bad like some people said, i know it is not really satisfying but i already play games that has worse ending than this.
Overall i gave this game 10/10

Condenses the entire mass effect trilogy into a single package.
Got this for 5 quid on sale, might as well have pirated it.

Initially I was going to stick with the original release for my next playthrough, but I ended up giving it a try due to the sale.

Legendary edition, compared to the original version, has way more modding options.
Gameplay-wise the games are the same except for LE1, which had the combat system greatly improved. 
The classic combat was serviceable, but not that good, this version feels much more responsive now.

https://www.nexusmods.com/masseffectlegendaryedition/mods/1500
Mods like these were the first things I installed for MELE, since its biggest flaw is that the technology being used is superior, but you can very clearly tell the design team is different and much less talented than the original team who made the game. A lot of the lighting is much more washed out and soulless, but you can correct it with mods like MELLO that preserve the original artstyle while still giving you the enhanced textures and gameplay.


TL;DR:
Gameplay in ME1 is enhanced, lots more mods than the original versions, and puts all of the DLC in the base game so you don't have to go faffing about on EA's websites. 
Pinnacle Station from ME1 isn't in the game which is lame. 
But that's honestly forgiveable since after playing it in the OG version on my last playthru I can 100% confirm it's just a glorified arena.

Biggest flaw by far is the inferior lighting which makes the game look plasticy and soulless, but if you're willing to install some mods and the ME3Tweaks manager, you can rectify these errors.


Overall; wait for it to go on sale, and play with mods.

Ten years later, the dialog is still clunky, the ending is still trash, and the rest of it hits every bit as hard as it did the first time. LE also gives ME1 a much-needed upgrade to the bullet sponge tedium of the original game, and the mod scene is fantastic. Worth a purchase if you've never played, and worth a repurchase if you loved it the first time.

So far so good, mostly.

The great: Mass Effect. I figure if you're buying this so many years after it came out, you already know.

The good: Legendary Edition has a bunch of DLC and some bug fixes compared to the old versions. Graphics for ME 1 are better than I expected so far, and I have a cruddy workstation GPU. Haven't got to ME1 and ME2 yet.

The bad: the game is hard to launch. What happens is 1. Steam installs an app called "EA," aka the "EA Launcher?" Not sure. Then 2. EA Launcher runs a "wrapper" program that lets you pick which of the three ME games you want to play, then 3. the selected version plays.

The problem is that I CAN ONLY LAUNCH MASS EFFECT IF I KILL ALL EA PROCESSES FIRST. Not too bad so I won't gripe much about it. But after you play the game and close, some of the EA processes remain running, and for whatever reason that prevents ME from running again. You just get a busy icon briefly and then that's it. No error message or anything. Just doesn't work. But if you kill every process starting with "EA" and try again it works immediately.

I know some other people have given up and requested refunds over this so I figured I'd share my troubleshooting tip. Hope it helps.

The Mass Effect trilogy is a wonderful set of games and the Legendary Edition is the perfect package in which to play them. Each of the games is a solid third-person shooter, but where the game really shines is in its story.

As you play through each of the games, you can see how the developers refined the game to do away with tedious gameplay and increase the focus on the story. I think the third game drew some criticism for being less open than the previous games, but I don't think it's an issue.

One thing I will say that may not be clear to first-time players - this trilogy is designed to be played in order, in the same way you would watch a trilogy of movies. The character you create in the first game can then by imported into the second, and then again from the second to the third.

I cannot recommend this game enough. It's a truly cinematic and endearing experience that on completing will leave you feeling sad that it has ended.
