Mass Effect is arguably one of the greatest RPG series out there, and I don't believe we'll ever get to see an other trilogy like this one, which is a real shame, since it's probably the single best one out there. Even though the gameplay may feel a little clunky at times (especially in ME1, it starts getting better in ME2 though) the games manage to build a universe and a cast of characters which will stick with you for a long, long time. The bonds you build with them and the individual stories are unforgettable, even though there are some issues here and there. Over the entire trilogy you get to make lots of choices, some small, some literally deciding the fate of an entire race, and getting to shape your personal role in this story is one hell of an experience.

All three games are great and I'd highly recommend them, but if I had to rank them I'd go with ME1<ME2<ME3. This isn't supposed to mean that ME1 is bad by any means, quite the opposite actually! IT's probably got the best main villain in the entire trilogy and offers some amazing world building, does a great job at introducing all of the characters and offers an atmosphere which the other two Mass Effects don't quite have. The outstanding issue is the clunky gameplay to me though - the mission design and gunplay is fine, it's old, but not too bad overall, but the exploration of uncharted worlds (which offer a great atmosphere) and the side missions linked to them can start to become a pain at some point. I personally had a really hard time exploring some of those planets because navigating in the Maco was just hella painful at times, but the dialogue and choices I got to made during the main story compensated that.

Mass Effect 2 was a big step up, both gameplay and graphic wise: The models and textures look a lot better, the gunplay starts to feel a lot more like the shooters from the 2010 era, and the addition of lots of all new squadmates and the constant dread of everything possibly going wrong are amazing. Side quests have also been vastly improved, now being actual missions instead of driving around in the clunky Mako over and over again.

Now, to my favorite, ME3: As much as it has suffered from not getting enough time and having a rather shitty ending it's still my favorite. A lot (sadly not all, there are some plotholes here and there) storylines are coming to an end, you get to make some of the biggest choices of the entire series and ultimately finally get to face the terror of the villains which were built up throughout the entire trilogy. It truly has that feeling of everything is going to end right here and now, and I can't recall anything ever shattering my heart as often as ME3 did. On a side note, it also includes the Citadel DLC, which is probably my all time favorite DLC - it's short, but it offers so many great moments with your squad, I can't even count them!

Overall, Mass Effect is one of the greatest RPGs out there - if you haven't played it yet, I envy you, so go ahead and pick it up on sale, you're not gonna regret it.

Mass Effect is one of my all-time favourite games, and this collection offers the best way to play it by a landslide.
The gameplay is rebalanced perfectly, with combat feeling smooth and fun, controls feeling more refined, and AI redone to fit with the environments and cover options, as opposed to the vanilla version where everyone rushes towards you, not just the Krogans and Geth Juggernauts. Not only that, but the boss fights are fun, and the Mako has never felt better to drive.
But the main reason this game is so timeless is the storyline, or more specifically, the CHOICE SYSTEM. With the exception of Alpha Protocol, I can't name any other game where choice matters this much: Every side quest and story mission has you making a major choice, each one with benefits and drawbacks, and rather than slamming you as the villain for choosing a more brutal tactic, you're instead considered an anti-hero; or "Renegade". 
I personally feel that no matter which class you pick between Soldier, Engineer, Vanguard, Biotic, etc., the best way to play is to balance out between both peaceful and brutal choices, as some of the choices you have to make in this game offer some genuine moral dilemmas and you have to think about the consequences each one entails. So it's for the best to consider both possibilities and the implications thereof.
Combine this with a rich universe, fantastic cast of characters, and a nigh-uncanny balance of a dark, mature storyline with thought-provoking themes and a sense of wonder, discovery and cautious optimism, and you have a Role Playing Game that shines brighter than any other from the seventh generation of gaming.

Oh, and you also get Mass Effect 2 & 3. Those games are also really fantastic. 
Basically, if you haven't played Mass Effect and its sequels, THIS is the way to do so.

Game good.

== SHORT ==

- I really liked it!
- It took me 120 hours to finish the 3 games on Insanity difficulty and get all the achievements.
- Overall, the gameplay is fluid and has very few bugs.
- The story and soundtrack are exceptional!

== LONG ==

It's an epic trilogy, with a very well written story and charismatic NPCs. The Mass Effect trilogy greatly values ​​the power of choices, during all games you will have to make choices that could decide the fate of NPCs, as well as the availability of future quests.

The remastering was very well done and the integration of the 3 games into a single package improved the experience of importing saves and playing the 3 games as if they were a single product. Some individual observations:

- ME1: The vehicle gameplay is a bit clunky and the physics are a bit crazy, so if you want to explore all the planets and do all the quests, you might get bored, but it's tolerable. Furthermore, weapon management is also a bit tedious, you will have to manage all weapons (and their upgrades) for all squadmates.

- ME2: The gameplay is very good, everything works as expected and the combat is very satisfying. The weapons management system has been improved (simplified) compared to ME1, as well as the mechanics of exploring planets and obtaining resources. The squadmates' individual missions are the icing on the cake, allowing you to create greater bonds with NPCs and learn more about their background. In short, ME2 is a masterpiece.

- ME3: After finishing ME2, you may find ME3 a little opaque and lifeless, this is normal. Everything will seem a little darker and more hopeless, several aspects contribute to this: the color palette, the number of crew members on the Normandy and the progression of the story towards its apocalyptic ending. However, this contrast in relation to ME2 is not the only "defect" of ME3, the gameplay has some balancing problems: I played ME1 and ME2 on the highest difficulty and always using the Soldier class, in ME3 it was only possible to play using Adept class (full biotic) making power combos with squadmates, otherwise it was almost impossible to last more than 5 seconds against enemies - I noticed this very early in my Soldier run, forcing me to delete my Soldier save from ME3 and start a new save as Adept (after researching this balancing problem on the internet). This cost me a few wasted hours of gameplay, moreover, I would have liked to have finished the 3 games as Paragon Soldier on Insanity difficulty, but it wasn't possible, life goes on.

And finally, here are some tips:

- Choose before you start ME1 whether you will opt for a Paragon (good guy) or Renegade (bad guy) attitude. When you choose, be consistent and maintain this behavior in the 3 games, your story will be much more concise and you will have access to exclusive dialogues.

- If you are trying to play on Insanity difficulty, remember that in ME3 it is very difficult to be efficient with any class other than the Adept.

- Keep an eye on the side quests, there are several super interesting minor characters and quests that start in ME1 and ME2 and have relevant developments that are only resolved in the last game.
A must for anyone who loves Mass Effect or space games. A faithful upgrade from the original.

I've never played the original editions but I honestly really enjoy this collection very much.
The narrative and the story are fantastic. The lore is complex and well thought out. I love the characters and some choices I have to make in the plot are very difficult, because all options are not simply black and white and risk sometimes even the life of your squad members. 
I have only a few things to critisize about the story. My own main character lacks a bit of personality even if I chose the precostumized John or Jane Shepard, but that's not a big issue when you play around a fantasic squad. The other problem is the dialogue wheel, because the options are always an unpercise summed up version of what the character says, sometimes even so missunderstandable that my character says completely differents things than I want him to.
What I like especially about this edition is the relation between the games. When you start the game you land in a menu where you can chose between the 3 games independetly, but you can import your character and all your choices to the following game when you finished the one before. Even if you are more interested in Mass Effect 2 and 3 I would suggest you to start with the first game because it's a very good introduction in the world and the story and no video game series like Mass Effect feels more like a true trilogy like Mass Effect where all games match together.
The gameplay is very enjoyable but still feels like an 15 year old game series with some little bugs. Especiallly in Mass Effect 1 the movement is clunky and the enemy AI is a little bit dumb. But once you're in the mechanics that's also not an big probkem, because you enjoy fantastic dialogues, some cool riddles and still have fun to shoot some aliens.
The biggest issue about this game is that you need the EA App and an EA Account to launch even if you have the game normally on Steam and even though it's an offline single-player game. The EA app is honestly horrible and has many errors. Therefore I often have problems to even start this game and have to restart my computer. But once you're in the game you shouldn't have any stability, so I didn't had yet any.
The world bulding is fantastic but I wouldn't suggest you to fly to every planet because some of them lack a bit of content and not all of the side quests there are so interesting as in games like The Witcher 3, but you can easily avoid all of them and focus simply on the main story without big problems.
All in all, Mass Effect Legendary is a fantastic game collection that every fan of role-playing games and epic sci-fi sagas like Star Wars and Dune should check out. For fans who already played the original gamess it's probably not as worthy because it doesn't feel like much about the games had changed, but I personally never played the original ones, as said before, and on some other internet platforms it's relatively cheap for 3 games together.

Mixed feelings on the remaster; it didn't spruce up the visuals much despite the massive storage increase over the OG games (more than double the original trilogy combined), and the EA 3rd party BS is entirely unnecessary. The games aren't all in the same executable either, instead it's a launcher that boots the game you select. But the save importing to sequels is completely seamless, you can finally get ME3 on Steam, and the best space RPG is available in one convenient package.

Reviewing the games themselves is a bit of a waste. They're still the record-breaking, award-winning RPGs of yore. They still fill me with wanderlust and the normal kind of lust when interacting with the many romantically available aliens. ME3 was the first game that made me cry actual tears, that made me actually grieve a fictional character, and the story hasn't gone anywhere.

If you're new, I beg you to play the whole trilogy back to back to back, but realistically, ME1 only holds up in terms of raw storytelling chops. ME2 took a lot of inspiration from the then-popular Gears of War and the cover-shooting is objectively much stronger; there're several reasons it's widely regarded as the best of the trilogy. ME3 remains my favorite, but only because it builds on all your effort, your relationships and accomplishments of the two games prior.

Please please please please play Mass Effect. Andromeda was a letdown, but the franchise doesn't deserve to get the EA double barrel to the back of the skull for that. It's a magnificent world with genuinely mindbending levels of flavor text and worldbuilding for you to sink your teeth into. It's an easy to follow, easy to get lost in, easy to love story of one hero standing in defiance of the end of the world despite impossible odds. Moral decisions, gray areas, duty conflicting with emotions... Many games have taken inspiration since, but none have surpassed.

True classics. ME1 is very reminiscent of KOTOR in its presentation and general feel. I found the Mako and planetside side missions to be arduous grinds; the payoff for a lot of the side missions was minimal in the first game (i.e., one or two conversations). However some quests (like UNC: Rogue VI) have payoffs in later games that really do reward you for taking a single character through all three games. Generally these games do a very good job with cross-game tie-ins and callbacks to decisions to you made previously that do make the games feel connected. Overall I found ME1 by itself to be fairly dated and I think first time players would have a rough time with it. The paragon -- renegade system was interesting at the time but reads as quite binary given the development of the rpg genre in the years since.

ME2 stands up much better today. The overarching plot is weaker, but the strength of ME2 is in its cast of colorful characters. The most enjoyable content in ME2 were the side conversations and loyalty missions, where you could learn about your companions and help them to grow as characters. The planet-scanning grind was very annoying. The final mission was enjoyable, even if the "big bad" was not particularly memorable. The combat was streamlined in ME2 in a way I found more enjoyable, while being slower than ME3, which I think made combat too fast. The combat experience in ME2 was overall my favorite, and I think ME2 was my favorite of the three games.

ME3 comes off as much more plot-driven than ME2. The companion roster is smaller, which by itself wouldn't necessarily be an issue, but several are recurring characters. While there is enjoyable character growth with some of the new characters, several reappearing companions do not appreciably grow over the course of the game, such that their appearance feels a bit like fan service in the sense that the developers may have been scared of fan disapproval if they altered the characters too much. The obvious example of this for me was Garrus, who I enjoyed from ME2 -- he has a few moments of growth in ME3 where he discusses how he feels about his people looking to him for leadership, but other than these few moments he reads fairly flat for the rest of the game. For a game that is shifting to a greater focus on plot than its predecessors, it falters in that focus. The overarching goal of uniting the galaxy to combat the reaper threat is understandable, but it is marred by fetch quests to scan Reaper-controlled systems for random widgets. It feels bad to alter the entire future of the krogan race, only to spend the next half hour collecting doodads for fetch quests with no gameplay. There is also relatively little payoff for these side quests, other than reaching the magic "strength number" needed to get the "good ending." The combat in ME3 was too fast for me personally, with many encounters taking only a few minutes. Perhaps that could be rectified by playing on a harder difficulty. The presentation of ME3 is pretty good, but the narrative and characters falter relative to ME2. I would say they are still good relative to the RPG genre as a whole, but ME3 was not the conclusion to the trilogy that I was hoping for. 

However, the ME trilogy stands as one of the defining RPG franchices of the early 2000s for a reason. Aspects of these games, like the party dynamics and the paragon -- renegade system, had profound effects on the RPG genre as a whole, and the success of ME showed the industry that sci-fi was a commercially-viable genre, a fact most fans are grateful for. My final verdict is that these games ask you put up with a lot of downtime and grind, with gameplay that is not exactly stellar by today's standards, but in return they offer some truly memorable moments and characters that I think, in the end, are worth the trouble.
Be prepared for an emotional journey of love and loss. I would give my left kidney to be able to play this trilogy again for the first time.

Mass Effect (the series) is a classic Action RPG that has influenced the entire medium of videogame storytelling. From its choice-based dialogue trees to its deep leveling, exploration, & combat systems, the Mass Effect series paved the way for blockbuster games like Baldur's Gate 3. Bioware games have a heavy emphasis on companions, & look no further (especially Mass Effect 2) than this series to find friends, foes, & romance among those who would help you save the galaxy. Be a Paragon of virtue or a self-serving Renegade. Pick the collection up on one of the frequent sales & rise to be the saviour or fall to be the villain of an entire galaxy of living, breathing beings.

It always starts with the same question: is it really that good?

I mean, perhaps my tastes were simpler back then, less critical, more lowbrow. I rack up my brain trying to remember details of my playthroughs, but come up empty -- I remember liking it, sure, but cannot pinpoint exactly why, and the scattered screenshots in my hard-drive aren't of much help. So I boot it up again, and a hundred hours later, I end up with the same response I always do: yes, it's that good.

I have played the Mass Effect trilogy three times in my life, and if life allows me, I'll do it a few more times before I die.

Here's a secret nobody tells you, and one that I always forget: Mass Effect is, at its core, a character-based story. The characters are not particularly deep or complex, true, but each is interesting in their own way, and seeing them interact with each other and the world is the beating heart of this franchise. Everything ends and begins with the characters: we care about the worldbuilding because we see the world through their eyes; we think before making our choices because we know that they will react; we care about the mission because we want to see them survive; we keep playing because they are fun to be around.

It is also why I don't like Mass Effect 2 that much: too few interactions between characters. Its modular structure provides the player with some vague notion of agency, sure, but it ends up creating a narrative structure that's too hard to script for: how can you make the character react to the last mission if it can be any mission in the game? Or, conversely, how can you make two characters interact if you don't know at which point they are in their loyalty quest lines? No wonder that they simply gave up trying to do these things; in ME2, everyone stays in their own room of the ship, completely oblivious to each other and the world around them. For them, only Shepard exists, and nothing else. This would be a reasonable decision if modular shooting missions is what people love in ME -- but it's not. People like the characters, the banter. "Do I recruit Tali or Garrus first?" is an empty choice that no one cares about, one that ends up having no consequence whatsoever, apart from its existence making it too hard for them to talk to each other.

Thankfully, in ME3 they fixed it all. The storyline is more linear, sure, but that's a small price to pay for hearing what everybody has to say about the last mission. Your crew members react. Talk to each other. Move around the ship. The Normandy feels alive in ME3, in a way that had not been seen since the between-mission meetings à la Star Trek of ME1, where you could hear Wrex talking shit about Liara before she mind-fuck-massaged you in front of everyone. Those were the best moments in ME1, and it's incredible to see them resurface here in ME3.

The crowning jewel is, of course, the Citadel DLC: a mission that can best be described as "what if Mass Effect was a sitcom?". This DLC is, in essence, a big get-together party with the ship's current and previous crew, containing hundreds of lines of interaction between characters that, up until now, had only a dozen lines speaking to each other. In that sense, playing the DLC is like diving into the chocolate river at Wonka's Factory: a delicious thing that you rarely experienced, but now a thousand-fold, almost too much to contain. It makes you want to drown, to be there forever, hearing what Zaeed and Wrex have to say to each other, seeing how Tali gets when she drinks. They're your friends, and they're here.

The designers got it. In the end, they got it -- they realized what it was all about, and doubled down on it. It's beautiful.

I have now played the Mass Effect trilogy four times in my life, and if life allows me, I'll do it a few more times before I die. The shooting kind of sucks, some missions are boring, and Shepard is a Mary Sue -- yes to all above. But no game has ever come close to being such a nice friendsfest, and in that regard, ME continues to reign supreme.

I was a mere young boy and didn't understand the messages behind these stories. Many years would past and I would forget these tails of trials and tribulations. However on a random Saturday night I would find the legendary edition on sale. 80% off, what a steal. I remember hearing the stories, how this is one of, if not, the greatest trilogy of games ever created. That led me into an experience like no other. Many people play games and enjoy them. They enjoy the rush, the thrill, the story, the ups and downs. This game is not something you enjoy, it is something you experience. I went into this game with the knowledge that their was someone named Commander Shepard and there was big robots and alien sex maybe. How naive I was. The feeling you get whilst playing this trilogy is unexplainable. Every action matters. Your character will stay with you from start to end. Your experiences are their experiences and their experiences are your experiences. By the time you reach the ending of the 2nd game, you have peaked in your gaming career. Then the hash realities of what we call 'life' showcased in a grand display of symbolism the world has never seen. An unforgetable experience. The sound design was created by divine beings who are unlike anything we have ever seen or heard. I am truly saddened that I only get that true 'wow' factor playing this game once. Yes this game has great replayablitiy, but nothing with compare to your first playthrough. I have ascended by playing this game.

Overall 11/10, I cannot wait for the true 4th game when Mass Effect returns (Sorry Andromeda was ass).

I can say without any doubt that this is the best trilogy I have ever played, and without hesitation, I started another play through once I finished my first just to explore the options I missed. I'm going to start another the minute I finish my current one. This trilogy is so rich with lore, incredibly well-written with beautifully crafted characters, an amazing soundtrack, and fantastic gameplay. It starts off as a slow-burn, but I seriously recommend going through with every side quest, every little optional thing, and just full-send it like that through the entire series to get the most out of your play through. I also cannot recommend enough playing as FemShep. Her voice acting is golden and enriches the experience exponentially. (Not to say BroShep's voice acting is horrible! I just love FemShep's dynamic voice.)

And yeah, I realize that EA's launcher is horrible, but if you manage to butt past it, the games themselves have little to no issues. I've only experienced two bugs and crashed once in my 172 hours of playing, and they weren't completely game-breaking (a note: manually save frequently in the first Mass Effect. Autosave doesn't occur as often as it does in the following games.)

The Gameplay and story are great. This is one of my favorite game story lines of all time.

I am not a fan of how the gameplay dynamic changes from game to game, however that was also the case in the original versions. Some of the changes were improvements and others made the game worse. Overall, it’s a wash between the two.

That said, the game port itself is absolutely awful, it is full of nonstop game ending bugs that where NOT present in the original versions of the game.

In ME1 the voice to video sync is off by as much 2 full seconds in cut scenes. At best it is noticeably off by around half a second.

In ME2 the game CONSTANTLY glitches. The sound sometimes stops playing any voice dialog, sometimes all the sound effects disappear, sometimes the music is gone. The only way to correct it is to quit and re launch the game. Unfortunately, you cannot just keep playing and ignore the sound issue because as soon as you cross any load zone after a sound glitch as happened the game will crash. Luckily this only seems to happen on the Normandy so the game remains playable.

ME3 same sound Sync issues as the first game. At least it doesn’t crash constantly.

Even with all the super annoying bugs I still recommend playing the game, but if you have the option to play the originals instead of this buggy port, do it.

Mass Effect Legendary Edition: A Rekindled Love Affair (Mostly)

Let me just say upfront: I adore the Mass Effect trilogy. Replaying it with the Legendary Edition was like catching up with old friends. The graphical upgrades, especially in the first game, are a significant improvement. Seeing the Citadel in its remastered glory? Breathtaking. The streamlined game play tweaks are welcome, too, particularly the Mako's improved handling (though it's still a bit…special).

The narrative, especially in Mass Effect 2, is a masterclass in character-driven storytelling. The suicide mission? Still an emotional roller coaster. And Mass Effect 3, despite its controversial ending (which, let's be honest, has been softened with the extended cut), still delivers a powerful punch. The sense of scale, the weight of your choices, the sheer epicness of the galactic conflict…it's captivating.

And then there's Tali. My Tali. From her shy, inquisitive introduction in the first game to her fierce loyalty and unwavering support throughout the trilogy, she's easily one of the best-written characters in gaming history. Her romance arc? Chef's kiss. I'm a sucker for a good love story, and Shepard's relationship with Tali is one for the ages. Seriously, BioWare, give me a Tali spin-off already!

Now, it's not all perfect. Some of the original jankiness remains, particularly in the first game's combat. And while the visual upgrades are generally fantastic, some textures and character models still show their age. But these are minor quibbles in the grand scheme of things.

Overall, the Mass Effect Legendary Edition is a must-have for fans of the series and a fantastic entry point for newcomers. It's a reminder of why these games are considered classics, and it reignited my love for this incredible universe. Now, if you'll excuse me, I'm off to start another play through. For Tali, of course. ;)

Extra notes:

Okay, look, I've poured over 100 hours into this trilogy, seen everything, done everything, romanced everyone (for research purposes, obviously), and I'm here to declare, definitively, once and for all: Tali'Zorah vas Normandy is the best. End of discussion.

I know, I know. Liara T'Soni has her legions of fans. The blue alien archaeologist, with her powerful biotics and evolving personality? She's a great character, no doubt. And yeah, she's probably Shepard's best match. Key word: Shepard's. Not mine.

My Shepard's heart belongs to Tali. Her quirky engineering genius, her unwavering loyalty, her adorable awkwardness, the way her voice cracks when she's nervous...it's all just perfect. Plus, that whole forbidden love aspect? The cultural differences they overcome? The vulnerability she shows beneath her mask? Come on! It's romance gold.

So, while Liara might be the "canon" best romance, the one BioWare pushes the hardest, Tali is the one that truly resonates with me. She's the one I think about long after the credits roll. She's the one I'd build a fleet of starships for. She's my best. And after 100% completing this legendary saga, I'm even more convinced of that fact.

This review for the Mass Effect series is long overdue, to say the least. The games are so beloved that I'm not even sure that my Positive endorsement matters at this point. Here it goes anywho...

Mass Effect is a story-rich, action-packed, RPG that takes you on a wild ride as the main protagonist, Commander Shepard. The trilogy reminds me of being engrossed in a good science fiction book series, but is even better because you get to make key decisions in your Shepard's journey. I like Mass Effect for the same reason that I like Star Trek: The Next Generation- The dynamic that exists between a diverse crew and a captain that knows the crew members as individuals, utilizes each of their strengths, and unites the crew for a common cause. The crew members in Mass Effect have uniquely different flaws, strengths, beliefs, skills, and backgrounds. I enjoyed getting to know each character, and loved watching my crew/friends work together to accomplish amazing feats. The interactions between the characters, as well as the character growth, are also believable. Shepard and the crew members all grow and change as individuals over the course of the series, in the same way that positive influences and trauma shape actual people. 

I am currently on another play through of the trilogy, in an effort to earn most of my remaining achievements while enjoying the story once more. This leads me to the one and only complaint that I have in regard to Mass Effect: My Shepard will not have a random love affair in ME2 and I will therefore never have all three Paramour achievements. This means that I will be missing one achievement for the entire trilogy. My Shepard's romantic partner is unavailable during ME2 because he is away on a mission, and he is also emotionally and morally conflicted over Shepard's reappearance and Shepard's alliance with questionable entities. His feelings, although very frustrating, are understandable. (My Shepard put herself in his boots for a moment, decided to give him time, polished her heart on her sleeve, and then saved the whole fancy universe some more.) I believe that all three Paramour achievements should be granted to players that remained loyal to stubborn and driven romantic partners that were only available in ME1 and ME3, so that those players have the opportunity to reach a "Perfect Game" achievement-wise. There is something commendable about a Shepard that knows exactly what they want and who sternly, but politely, declines easy hanky-panky. ...I guess my game will have to be Imperfectly Perfect or Perfectly Imperfect.

There is nothing i can say about this game that hasn't been said before. The mass effect trilogy is a masterpiece and the Legendary Edition is simply the best way to play it. It is still the same great games and the minor changes that have been made are for the better. The flaws of the original games are still there and most of the problems people will have are probably going to be with ME:1. (It is the first, and it plays like it).   But in the grand scheme of things the flaws of the games are minor. The largest thing I personally had an issue with is the pre-rendered cut scenes are in their original resolution (I believe 720p). Makes sense since a remaster is just that, a remaster, not a remake. 90% of the cut scenes in the game are in engine however so it will be rare to notice this. Just an observation on my side, and depending on what resolution you play in this might not even be noticeable or a problem. I cannot recommend this game enough.  If you have never played the Mass Effect Trilogy  you are doing yourself a disservice. Get it, play it, love it, you wont regret it. 10/10.

I bought the legendary edition in the discount for 6 bucks, and I've never played ME before this edition, so my review is from a non-nostalgic standpoint. So far I'm currently still playing through ME1 (close to the end though, at least that's what it feels like), so a review for 2 and 3 will appear later. 

ME1: Verdict: Pretty darn entertaining space opera. Sometimes you can tell the game is running on an old engine, the side-quests can become repetitive (land on planet -> enter building -> shoot things -> activate something -> done) and some of the game mechanics are, although still fun, somewhat old-fashioned. But this entire game is about the characters and roleplaying, and Bioware nailed that. The voice-acting is (mostly) pristine, and both the characters and story are well written. The cutscenes play out as action sequences, and I only discovered about 15 hours into the game that dialogue is skippable (by accident), as it is THAT entertaining to listen to, even with the irrelevant side-content. I can also now see how a lot of other rpg's out there have taken inspiration from this game in terms of dialogue and possible choices to make. I can see how this game was the absolute bomb back in the day, given well the rpg-elements are implemented, which is very impressive for a game from 2007. Solid game, would have payed the original price as well for it. 
For ME1: 7.5/10

I did read in other reviews that choices made in ME1 carry over to ME2 and ME3, so I'm really looking forward to that. Sounds quite interesting and I'm not sure how many games have done that before ME did that.

Play the games in chronological order, you'll thank me later. The world building is immaculate and progresses really smoothly along the trilogy. The gameplay choices carry over from games 1,2 and 3 really well. Unfortunately the ending of game 3 is somewhat of a disappointment and quite frankly ignores all your choices, but 95% of the gameplay is still affected by your choices in and between the games. Companions who die are remembered, events you caused are noted and commented, and you have some unique carry-over choices based on what you did in an earlier game. Especially the major choices of MSE2 influence your options in MSE3 greatly. 
Now, to the actual review.
IMO: MSE1 has the most genre-fitting gunplay and my preferred inventory and item system and the most RPG-elements by far (combat is quite similar to Halo 1 and 2), but is otherwise quite clunky (in a homely sort of way). MSE2 has the best companions and 50% of the best side-content, and my favorite lvl-up/progression-system. MSE3 has mostly cool action and the best visuals, good quality of life improvements compared to the two earlier games and the most casual lvl-up-system, the least RPG elements, 30% of the best side content (two longer side-quest lines in particular), fewer impactful choices discounting killing/saving some followers (basically choose which lives and dies). My biggest problem with MSE3 is that the combat feels really restricted by the newly implemented weight-system (only in MSE3), and the variety of biotic/tech powers available to the player during a single playthrough is really underwhelming. Otherwise the combat and movement is the smoothest of the three games by far, it's just a shame that using cool guns effectively makes you unable to use you powers (the more your equipment weighs, the longer your cooldowns are). Also, almost all your armor either gives power bonuses, or weapon bonuses. A balanced build is hard to make work, unlike in MSE1 where lvl-ups and the weapons themselves had most of the stats.

TLDR: MSE1 best gear system and most genre-fitting gunplay and the most RPG-elements of the three games, but the worst quality of life gameplay-wise and feels its age as clunkiness.
MSE2 most of the best side-content, most rewarding exploration, best companions and mediocre combat (not the best or worst). Also the median quality of life and over all RPG-ness of the trilogy.
MSE3 has the smoothest combat, movement and quality of life, but also an annoyingly limiting weight system and only bare-boned RPG elements. MSE3 might be THE casual RPG of the 2010s. Also MSE3 has the worst PC keybinding options of the trilogy and a pretty disappointing ending that kinda undercuts all of your choices during the whole trilogy. Still probably the best game trilogy I've ever played.

The fact that I played the whole trilogy in 5 days (89h of gameplay in 120h) and pulled two all-nighters doing so, might tell you something about the merits of this masterpiece of worldbuilding and action-packed casual RPG greatness.

In order to recommend Mass Effect, perhaps one of the greatest science fiction video game trilogies in existence, I must first give some context. I played these games as they released beginning in 2008 shortly after the release of ME1. Up until the end of ME3, me and everyone else at the time were captivated, utterly mesmerized by these games. Rightfully so. However, it was the ending of this franchise that put everyone off. You know what I speak of. The colors, the...star child thingy. Space magic. 

Quickly taking to the internet, it was a year that myself and many others begged developers to change the ending, tweak it, allow our Shepard to be victorious AND live to tell about their adventures. It never happened. Artistic integrity, they claimed, among many other things. We wrote hundreds of letters and even sent their studio trays of cupcakes, all vanilla flavored with red, blue and green frosting. We put up a good fight but ultimately nothing came of it save for a short freeze frame video montage at the end. An "epilogue". 

I had sold my copies a decade ago, believing the story of Shepard to never be retold or experienced ever again. Then, early this year, I saw this Legendary Edition on sale shortly after stumbling on the Nexus Mod page for the game. People had created mods for the game, important mods too. Integral mods that would bring this franchise back into the light of day and glory. Everything from the Audemus Happy Ending Mod that removes the star child from the game and allows your Shepard to be the hero you spent three whole games creating defeat the reapers and WIN, to the mod that restores the camera shot of Miranda's butt. It's all there and they are wonderful. 

There's no better time to play these titles now that moders have given their blood sweat and tears making them right, epic and how they were dreampt to be by players everywhere before that swift kick between the legs at the end of ME3. Now you can play them properly and finish the fight with honor.

SPOILERS AHEAD
This is one of the best games ive ever played in the 2 or 3 years ive been here on steam. the story is awesome( except for how it ends on mass effect 3), the characters are written brilliantly and get you to love them if they're meant to(except for both Jacob and Morinth), and the romances are great as well(Except for Jacob and morinth again as well as the me 1 romances, although it aint the devs fault for me 1 romances). gameplays also great. now while nearly most everything about the mass effect trilogy is awesome, there are of course the cons. one problem i had with mass effect 1 is the Mako you have to use. that thing is a big pain and incredibly annoying. other than that, mass effect 1 is great. for mass effect 2, it was nearly perfect, incredibly perfect, but there are a few problems. Both Jacob and Morinth. Jacob feels like there wasnt much effort put into his character or anything like that, but rather a last minute addition. something that contradicts his character is that he supposedly hates thane for being a hired killer, but jacob himself is literally a hired gun, so some obvious hypocrisy right there, which may or may not have been intended, probably not tho. something else they could have done with Jacob considering his disdain for assassins was have him get in a fight with thane like tali and legion did along with Miranda and Jack, but they didnt't and missed out on a good opportunity to further implement his dislike for assassins. His romance is incredibly boring and hes cringey during it and even worse, if you romanced him in ME 2, he straight up cheats on you with another woman in ME 3 and gets her pregnant. He literally badmouths Garrus and Thane i think if you romance Garrus or thane over Jacob. he doesn't even do anything remotely useful in Mass Effect 3 and literally kicks back and just watches us do all the hard work in fighting the reapers. the only reason i bothered doing his loyalty mission and kept him alive was because i really don't like any of the characters dying if i had a chance to save them, even if i'm not that invested with them and i wanted the Achievement for keeping everyone alive. One of the worst characters in mass effect. For Morinth, she's basically the same as Samara and there's no point in even choosing her over samara. you may think "maybe i could romance her instead since samara doesn't want to do a romance." While you are right, its literally a huge waste of time trying to get with her. if you choose to romance her and let her mind meld with you, she straight up fries your brain and you die and get a game over screen too. It further just proves the point that she's more of a detriment than actually being useful in the game. in mass effect 3, she disappears after ME 2 only to return as a banshee, being not only utterly useless once again, but also detrimental. just let Samara kill her unless you're trying to go the renegade route, now for mass effect 3. the game was pretty good, but there were some huge flaws with it, the most obvious being the damn endings you get. I kid you not, literally all of the endings in mass effect 3 sick. no matter what, your character cant survive save for the supposed canon ending of me 3 in which they somehow survive, but even then the ending is crap because while you do end up killing the reapers, you end up killing the geth(them cute robot bois) as well as EDI. in my opinion, there is no good ending for mass effect 3, no matter what. they all suck. Who knows, maybe that's what they were going for when they made the endings. maybe the devs wanted to show that while sometimes, we can get lucky and get a pretty good end like in mass effect 1 and 2, we cant always get what we want and that in war, the people we love can die no matter how hard we try to save everyone, that sometimes people will die whether we want them to or not. If they were though, they certainly haven't made that clear to us at all for over a decade. So until they decide to say that that's what they wanted for us to understand and provide proof, I'm still gonna say that the endings are complete bullshit because i wanted to see my commander Shepard settle down with Tali'vas Normandy on a nice place on earth. That's all im gonna say about ME 3 since i took up alot of time with it. While the Mass effect 3 endings are complete Trash, That is overpowered by both Mass Effect 1 and 2 and that's why you should buy this game. Well worth the money

Great series

This has been a very interesting experience. Mass Effect 1 is still incredibly bad. I felt this way in 2007 and playing the remaster in 2024 has only sharpened this critique. Every part of it - other than the worldbuilding - is a miss. Combat doesn't work, there is zero character development, the RPG part is a non-entity, the Mako is bad, and major plot points aren't even really incorporated. But, if you focus on main content, it's a breezy 10 hours or so.

Then and now, it is crazy how much better a game Mass Effect 2 is. It's like they finally delivered the game they intended. I haven't finished it yet, but I will, and quickly as I am struggling to put it down. It doesn't feel like a dated experience at all. Plus, with all the DLC incorporated from the start, there are a lot of characters and experiences I missed the first time. Combat is tight and fun. Spells are more useful and interesting. The scanning mini-game is addictive and relaxing. Characters, with their loyalty missions, are much more interesting. 

I never actually played Mass Effect 3 - I was taking a break from video games and its original release had so much baggage. But, with 2 being so fun, I cannot wait to finally dive in.

Note: Review written after Mass Effect 1 and most of Mass Effect 2.
